question: What was the first publicly-funded post-secondary technical institution in Hong Kong?
When was the Government Trade School founded?
What was the initial name of the Government Trade School?
data.answer: The first publicly-funded post-secondary technical institution in Hong Kong was the Government Trade School, founded in 1937. It was initially named the Government Trade School.

question: When did the Hong Kong Technical College get its name?
What was the Hong Kong Technical College renamed to?
In which year did the Hong Kong Technical College change its name?
data.answer: The Hong Kong Technical College was renamed in 1947 to the Hong Kong Technical College.

question: When was the Hong Kong Polytechnic formally established?
What institution did the Hong Kong Polytechnic take over in 1972?
data.answer: The Hong Kong Polytechnic was formally established in August 1972, taking over the campus and staff of the Hong Kong Technical College.

question: When did the Institution attain full University status?
In which year did the Institution become a full-fledged University?
data.answer: The Institution achieved full University status in November 1994.

question: What is the current student population of the University?
data.answer: The University has a student population of about 28,000.

question: Where can you find more information about the campus and academic units of the University?
What is the website for more information about the University?
data.answer: You can find more information about the campus and academic units of the University on their comprehensive website at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/en/.

question: What is the structure of all PolyU academic programmes?
How do PolyU academic programmes respond to changing needs?
What benefits do students have due to the credit-based structure?
What is the value of credits in a credit-based programme?
data.answer: All PolyU academic programmes follow a credit-based structure. The adoption of a credit-based structure has enabled our study programmes to be more responsive to the changing needs of students, the professions, and the society. Students can take a range of subjects according to their interests and career plans and will have greater flexibility in pacing their studies.

question: How many hours of study are expected to earn one credit?
Is there a limit to the number of credits taken per semester at PolyU?
Where can students find detailed academic regulations for PolyU?
Where can undergraduate students find information on university requirements?
data.answer: To earn a credit, students are expected to take up about 35 to 45 hours of study (inclusive of contact hours, private study, etc.). Unless approved otherwise, the number of credits to be taken in each semester shall not exceed 21. The detailed academic regulations are available at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/ar/docdrive/university-calendar/HAR-Version-for-University-Calendar.pdf. Undergraduate students may also refer to the website of the Office of Undergraduate Studies (OUS) for details on the university requirements.

question: What is a NetID?
How is a NetID assigned?
What is the format of a NetID?
data.answer: All full-time and part-time students are assigned a Network Identity (NetID), which is the same as your Student Number but with the last alphabet in lowercase.

question: What is the purpose of a NetID?
What can you access with a NetID and NetPassword?
data.answer: With your NetID and NetPassword, you can have free access to the University’s central IT facilities and services, including eStudent, LEARN@PolyU, wired and wireless Internet connection, network storage, etc.

question: How is a PolyU Connect account related to the student number?
What services does PolyU Connect provide?
data.answer: A PolyU Connect account is based on the student number and provides email, communication, and collaboration services. It's used for important notices and information related to your study. PolyU Connect is where you can check messages from teachers and offices, including Academic Registry notices and Library notices.

question: What is the PolyULife mobile app?
What information does PolyULife provide?
data.answer: PolyULife is a native mobile app that helps students access essential information for study, such as personal class and exam timetables, payment due dates, and other notifications. It's available on App Store and Google Play.

question: Where can you obtain general information about the University?
What can you find on the PolyU Website?
data.answer: You can obtain general information about the University and useful information related to your studies and campus facilities on the PolyU Website at https://www.polyu.edu.hk.

question: Why is it important to change my NetPassword regularly?
What should I avoid doing with my NetPassword?
data.answer: For security reasons, you must change your NetPassword regularly, and you should never disclose your NetPassword to a third person. You are responsible for the actions taken using your NetID and NetPassword.

question: What can students access via eStudent at http://www.polyu.edu.hk/student/?
What is available on eStudent?
Where can students find study-related applications?
data.answer: Students can access various study-related applications provided by the Academic Registry via eStudent at http://www.polyu.edu.hk/student.

question: What types of information can be found online through eStudent?
What are the online services available on eStudent?
data.answer: The following types of information can be found online: Information (general information, subject search, and program search), My Profile (personal details and study information), My Subject Registration, My Timetable, My Results, Graduation, Application Forms, and My Advisor.

question: Where can students find notices about upcoming activities related to their study?
How can students stay informed about study-related activities?
data.answer: Notices on upcoming activities related to your study will be posted on eStudent. Students are advised to check this page regularly.

question: Are there links to other information/functions offered by the University on eStudent?
What additional resources are available on eStudent?
data.answer: Yes, students can also find links to various information/functions offered by other units of the University on eStudent.

question: How can I obtain the Programme Requirement Document for my program of study?
Where can I find information about my program's requirements?
data.answer: You will be issued a copy of the Programme Requirement Document for your program of study by the department offering the program at the commencement of your study.

question: What information does the Programme Requirement Document contain?
What details are included in the Programme Requirement Document?
data.answer: The Programme Requirement Document contains information on credit requirements, curriculum, program-specific assessment regulations, grading system, graduation requirements, and award classifications.

question: Can the Programme Requirement Document be updated?
Is the content of the Programme Requirement Document subject to change?
data.answer: Yes, the Programme Requirement Document may be updated by the program offering department from time to time. You will be informed of the changes as and when appropriate.

question: Where else can I find a copy of the Programme Requirement Document?
Is there another location where the document is available?
data.answer: A copy of the Programme Requirement Document can also be found in the PolyU Course Programmes Database of the Library.

question: Where can students access the Student Handbook?
How can students find the Student Handbook?
Is the Student Handbook accessible online?
data.answer: The Student Handbook is accessible from eStudent or at the Academic Registry (AR) website.

question: What does the Student Handbook contain?
What information is available in the Student Handbook?
data.answer: The Student Handbook contains essential information concerning general academic matters, general regulations and procedures, services and facilities for students, and various communication channels.

question: Where should students enrolling in postgraduate schemes/programs refer for additional information?
What is the resource for postgraduate students in terms of handbooks?
data.answer: Students enrolling on postgraduate schemes/programs should refer to the dissertation handbook at https://www2.polyu.edu.hk/ar/Polyu/PGDIS.

question: Are there specific handbooks for postgraduate students?
What additional handbook should postgraduate students check?
data.answer: Yes, postgraduate students should also refer to the dissertation handbook at https://www2.polyu.edu.hk/ar/Polyu/PGDIS.

question: What is the responsibility of the Academic Registry (AR)?
What areas does the Academic Registry cover?
What matters are handled by the Academic Registry?
data.answer: The Academic Registry (AR) is responsible for matters related to applicants and students, covering admissions, registrations, timetabling, examination, student records, certification, and awards.

question: Where can individuals find more details about the Academic Registry?
What is the web address for the Academic Registry website?
data.answer: You may visit the AR website at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/ar for more details.

question: How can individuals access frequently asked questions and answers related to the Academic Registry?
Where can I find the 'Help Centre' for the Academic Registry?
data.answer: You can click the “Help Centre” on the AR website at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/ar for frequently asked questions and answers.

question: Where is the Service Centre of the Academic Registry located?
What is the address of the Academic Registry Service Centre?
What is the location of the Academic Registry Service Centre?
data.answer: The Service Centre of the Academic Registry is located at Room M101 of the Li Ka Shing Tower.

question: How can students obtain various forms from the Academic Registry after the Centre is closed?
Is there a way for students to get forms from the Academic Registry after hours?
data.answer: Students can obtain various forms on a self-serviced arrangement after the Centre is closed.

question: What contact options are available for students to enquire with the Academic Registry?
How can students contact the Academic Registry?
What is the contact information for the Academic Registry?
data.answer: An automated interactive telephone hotline at (852)2333 0600 is available, and students may also enquire via email as listed on the AR website.

question: Where can individuals find the opening hours of the Academic Registry Service Centre?
What is the web address for the opening hours of the Academic Registry Service Centre?
data.answer: Please visit the AR website at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/ar/about-ar/contact-us/ for the opening hours of the Academic Registry Service Centre.

question: What office should I contact for programme-related information?
Where can I get information about the curriculum and assessment regulations of specific programmes?
data.answer: You can obtain most of the programme-related information from the general office of your programme offering department. Enquiries related to the curriculum, subject selection, and assessment regulations of specific programmes should be directed to your department or academic advisors.

question: What information should I provide when writing to the University?
If I want to make an enquiry in writing, what details should I include?
data.answer: If you wish to make an enquiry, a comment, or suggestion on matters concerning the University in writing, you are advised to provide your full name, student number, contact telephone number, address, and the programme enrolled. The University will not be able to take action on any correspondence which is anonymous (i.e. without information on the full name and student number).

question: When do I need to confirm enrolment on my programme?
What is the deadline for settling tuition fees and other fees for Semester One?
When should I settle relevant fees for Semester Two?
data.answer: You need to confirm enrolment on your programme on a semester basis by settling the relevant tuition fees and other fees (e.g. credit transfer, exemption, etc.) in August or September (for Semester One) and in the following January (for Semester Two).

question: How will I receive notifications about the fees I need to settle?
Where can I check the fee debit notes issued by the University?
When will I receive notification emails about fees for Semester One?
data.answer: You will receive the notification email via PolyU Connect Email from the Finance Office normally in August (for Semester One) and December (for Semester Two) on the fees that you need to settle. You can check at our Student Account Portal https://www40.polyu.edu.hk/fosae > Fees and Receipts > Outstanding Fees regarding the fee debit notes issued to you by the University and your payment status.

question: What do I need to do to confirm enrolment on a programme?
What is the process to confirm enrolment?
What is required to settle enrolment on a programme?
data.answer: To confirm your enrolment on a programme, normally you are only required to settle the fees and register for subjects for the semester concerned before the specified deadline.

question: Where can I find information about tuition fee payment schedules?
How can I access details about the Tuition Fee Payment Schedule?
What is the website for information on fee payment schedules?
data.answer: Tuition Fee Payment Schedule and details are available at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/ar/ under the AR Website > Students in Taught Programmes > Registration Information > Fee Payment or FO Website at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/fo/students/fee-and-payment/students-in-taught-programmes/tuition-and-other-fees > 5. Tuition fee payment schedules.

question: What will be issued upon the first registration on the study programme?
What entitles a student to the rights and privileges of a full-time or part-time student?
data.answer: Upon your first registration on the study programme, a student identity card will be issued to you. You are entitled to the rights and privileges of a full-time or part-time student, as appropriate, upon fulfilling the criteria for progression for the period, having duly paid the tuition and other fees (e.g., caution money), and having completed the subject registration procedures.

question: Why do I need to carry my student identity card?
When should I present my student identity card at PolyU?
data.answer: You need to present your student identity card when entering PolyU, and you should carry it at all times while on the University premises as it enables you to gain access to various facilities of the University. The student identity card will become invalid upon the cardholder’s completion of graduation requirements or cessation of study.

question: What happens to service provisions for students once their status has ended?
When will service provisions generally not be available for students?
data.answer: Different units have their own service provisions and effective service periods for different types of students. Generally speaking, service provisions will not be available once the student status has ended or students have completed their studies and are eligible for award, regardless of the expiry date printed on the student identity card.

question: Where can students or graduands get more information about service provisions and arrangements?
How can I find out about service provisions for students at PolyU?
data.answer: Students/Graduands can contact individual offices for more information (https://www.polyu.edu.hk/ar/docdrive/polyu-students/student-handbook/special_arrangements.pdf).

question: When do student identity cards normally expire?
What should I do if my student identity card expires and I am eligible to continue my study?
data.answer: Student identity cards will normally expire at the end of Semester One or an academic year. If you are eligible to continue with your study after the expiry of your student identity card, please collect the renewed student identity card at the Academic Registry Service Centre during office hours in the last week of August (for student identity cards expiring at the end of an academic year) or in the last week of January (for student identity cards expiring at the end of Semester One).

question: Where can I collect the renewed student identity card?
During which weeks should I collect the renewed student identity card?
data.answer: You can collect the renewed student identity card at the Academic Registry Service Centre during office hours in the last week of August (for student identity cards expiring at the end of an academic year) or in the last week of January (for student identity cards expiring at the end of Semester One).

question: Who is eligible to collect the renewed student identity card?
Is the renewal process applicable to students who have transferred to another programme of a different mode?
data.answer: The renewal process is applicable to students who are eligible to continue with their study after the expiry of their student identity card, including those who have transferred to another programme of a different mode (i.e. from full-time to part-time or vice versa).

question: What should I do with the student identity card?
How should I return the card to the university?
Where should I return the student identity card?
data.answer: You are advised to return the card in person to the Academic Registry.

question: Can you transfer your student identity card to someone else?
Is the student identity card transferable?
What is the status of student identity cards in terms of transfer?
data.answer: Student identity cards are not transferable.

question: What should I do if I prefer to return the card by post?
How can I prevent fraudulent use of the card I returning by post?
What precaution is suggested for returning the card by post?
data.answer: If you prefer to return it by post, you are urged to cut it into halves.

question: What are the consequences of lending your student identity card to someone else?
What actions can be taken if you misuse your student identity card?
What disciplinary actions may be taken for misuse of the student identity card?
data.answer: If you lend your student identity card or use a card that does not belong to you, you are liable to disciplinary actions, which may include temporary deprivation of student rights, suspension, or termination of studies.

question: How should I take care of my student identity card?
What is advised to prevent disciplinary actions related to the student identity card?
What precautions should I take with my student identity card?
data.answer: You should take good care of your student identity card.

question: What should I do if my student identity card is lost, damaged, or if I need to amend my name?
How can I apply for a replacement student identity card?
Is there a fee for getting a replacement student identity card?
data.answer: You should submit an application for a replacement online, and a replacement fee will be charged for the new student identity card.

question: What should I do if I find the original student identity card after getting a replacement?
Where should I return the original card if found after replacement?
What is the procedure for dealing with the original card if it is found later?
data.answer: If the original student identity card is subsequently found, you should immediately return it to the Academic Registry for cancellation.

question: Is it permissible to possess more than one student identity card for the same programme?
What is considered an offence in terms of possessing student identity cards?
What actions may be taken if you are found possessing more than one student identity card for the same programme?
data.answer: It is an offence to possess more than one student identity card for the same programme at any time during your studies at the University, and you shall be subject to disciplinary actions if found committing this offence.

question: What is the purpose of this personal information collection statement (PICS)?
Under what ordinance does this PICS fall?
Who is responsible for the personal data collected under this statement?
data.answer: This is a personal information collection statement under the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (“the Ordinance”).

question: What are the purposes of collecting personal data during the application for admission?
How is personal data used during the application process?
What is the role of personal data in the selection process for admission?
data.answer: The personal data provided during the application for admission will be used as a basis for selection, managing the application account, processing the application, identifying possible multiple applications, obtaining records of existing and previous studies, verifying identity and qualifications, conducting statistical analysis, research, surveys, quality assurance, review, facilitating communications between the applicant and PolyU, and for other purposes directly relating to any of the above.

question: What happens to the personal data if an application for admission is not accepted?
How is the personal data handled if the application is unsuccessful?
According to what policy will the personal data be disposed of if the application is not accepted?
data.answer: In case the application is not accepted, the personal data provided during the application will be disposed of according to the prevailing policy of PolyU.

question: What happens to the personal data upon admission as a student of PolyU?
What becomes of the personal data provided during the application once admitted as a student?
How is the personal data used once admitted to PolyU?
data.answer: Upon admission as a student of PolyU, the personal data provided during the application becomes part of the official student records.

question: What are some of the specific uses of personal data after admission as a student?
How is personal data utilized throughout the student's academic journey at PolyU?
In addition to admission, for what purposes is personal data used during the student's studies at PolyU?
data.answer: The personal data provided during application for admission, throughout the studies, and upon leaving PolyU is used for purposes such as managing application accounts, conducting statistical analysis, research, surveys, quality assurance, facilitating communications, and other purposes directly relating to these activities.

question: Under what ordinance is this personal information collection statement provided?
What is the purpose of this personal information collection statement?
Which ordinance does this statement fall under?
data.answer: This is a personal information collection statement under the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (“the Ordinance”).

question: What are some purposes for collecting personal information during study and upon leaving PolyU?
Why is personal information collected during study at PolyU?
For what reasons is personal information collected by PolyU during study and upon leaving?
data.answer: The purposes include processing applications for activities, services, and facilities provided by units and departments of PolyU or organizations associated with PolyU, managing alumni affairs, verifying student/graduate status, qualifications, and academic records, conducting statistical analysis, research, surveys, quality assurance and review, and facilitating communications between students and PolyU.

question: What is done with personal information in the case of admission to a jointly offered or collaborated programme?
Where might personal data be transferred in case of joint programmes?
Are there situations where personal data is transferred to partner institutions?
data.answer: In the case of admission to a programme jointly offered or collaborated by PolyU and its partner institution(s), personal data will be transferred to the partner institution(s) for various purposes mentioned in the statement.

question: What contact information is required in case of emergency?
Who should be provided as an emergency contact?
What is the procedure for providing emergency contact information?
data.answer: You are required to provide an emergency contact, other than yourself, in case of emergency.

question: Who has access to and handles your personal data at PolyU?
Is your personal data kept confidential at PolyU?
Who are the authorized individuals handling personal data at PolyU?
data.answer: PolyU will keep your personal data confidential, and only authorised staff members of PolyU will have access to and handle your personal data.

question: To whom may PolyU disclose or transfer your personal data?
What parties may receive your personal data within or outside Hong Kong?
For what purposes may your personal data be disclosed or transferred by PolyU?
data.answer: PolyU may disclose or transfer your personal data to PolyU’s student organisations and alumni organisations, agencies, service providers, contractors engaged in activities on behalf of PolyU, other education institutions, their subsidiaries, relevant organisations, and government authorities in Hong Kong or other places for verification of qualifications obtained from PolyU. This is solely for the purposes set out in paragraph (a) above.

question: Under what circumstances may PolyU disclose your personal data as required by law?
In what situations may PolyU disclose personal data in response to requests from law enforcement agencies?
When may PolyU disclose personal data to government departments or regulatory authorities?
data.answer: PolyU may disclose your personal data when authorised or required by law and in response to requests from law enforcement agencies, government departments, or regulatory authorities.

question: What rights do you have regarding your personal data held by PolyU?
What can you request in relation to your personal data at PolyU?
Is there a fee associated with data access requests at PolyU?
data.answer: You have the right to request access to and correction of your personal data held by PolyU. A fee may be imposed by PolyU for processing your data access request.

question: How can access and correction of personal data be performed during the application for admission and studies?
Which online platforms can be used for accessing and correcting personal data during studies at PolyU?
What is the process for accessing personal data during studies at PolyU?
data.answer: During the application for admission and studies, access and correction of personal data can be performed via the relevant online platforms (i.e., eAdmission for applicants and eStudent for students).

question: How should access of personal data not available on online platforms be made according to the Ordinance?
What is the procedure for accessing personal data not available online at PolyU?
Where should the Data Access Request Form be sent for personal data not available online according to the Ordinance?
data.answer: Access of personal data not available on online platforms according to the Ordinance should be made by completing the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance Data Access Request Form and sending it to the Academic Registry at ar.dept@polyu.edu.hk.

question: After graduation, how can access and correction of personal information in the alumni records be done?
Where can you access and correct personal information after graduation from PolyU?
What is the process for accessing personal information in alumni records after graduation?
data.answer: After graduation, access and correction of personal information in the alumni records can be done on “My Profile & eCard” at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/alumni.

question: How should access of personal information not available on the alumni website be made according to the Ordinance?
What is the procedure for accessing personal information not available on the alumni website?
Where should the Data Access Request Form be sent for personal information not available on the alumni website according to the Ordinance?
data.answer: Access of personal information not available at the alumni website according to the Ordinance should be made by completing the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance Data Access Request Form and sending it to the Alumni Affairs and Development Office at alumni@polyu.edu.hk.

question: What information is kept in permanent records?
What is monitored during your study?
What is kept for reference when certification is required?
data.answer: Besides the information collected at the time of application, your registration details and assessment results are also kept in your permanent records for monitoring your progress during your study and for reference when certification is required.

question: What information is published in the Graduates List?
Who is mentioned in the Graduates List?
What details are included for students with First Class Honours and Distinction?
data.answer: Names of graduates, together with information on the award title, and classification of award (for students with First Class Honours and Distinction only), will be published in a Graduates List for the use of Congregation.

question: When might the University write to your secondary school?
Under what circumstances does the University express gratitude to your secondary school?
Why would the University contact your secondary school?
data.answer: The University might also write to your secondary school to thank them for sending a good student to the University in case you have been awarded a First Class Honours Degree or a Distinction in your studies.

question: Which departments may keep records related to your study?
Who maintains records related to your study?
Where are records related to your study kept?
data.answer: Your programme offering departments may also keep records related to your study.

question: Which offices keep records if you have requested/used services?
Where are records kept if you use services provided by the University Health Service, the Library, the Student Affairs Office, etc.?
What records are kept if you utilize services offered by specific offices in the University?
data.answer: If you have requested/used services provided by the University Health Service, the Library, the Student Affairs Office, the Information Technology Services Office, and the Campus Facilities and Sustainability Office or any other offices in the University, appropriate records will also be kept by these offices.

question: Who has access to student data?
Which departments/staff can access student data?
data.answer: Only authorised departments/staff of the University.

question: When will student data be deleted?
What determines the deletion of student data?
data.answer: Student data will be deleted when they are no longer required according to the relevant rules.

question: How often are retention policies reviewed?
Who reviews retention policies regularly?
data.answer: Retention policies will be reviewed regularly by the respective offices.

question: What is the right granted by the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance?
Under the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance, what rights do you have?
data.answer: You have the right to access and correct your personal data and also to request a copy of such data.

question: How can one access personal data?
What is the process to access personal data in the records?
data.answer: You may submit a request via the 'Data Access Request Form', obtainable at the Academic Registry Service Centre. A handling fee will be charged.

question: Where can the 'Data Access Request Form' be obtained?
From where can one get the 'Data Access Request Form'?
data.answer: The 'Data Access Request Form' is obtainable at the Academic Registry Service Centre.

question: Who may send information concerning study and registration?
Which offices may send information about study and registration?
data.answer: Your department or lecturers/advisors and offices of the University, such as Academic Registry, Library, Information Technology Services Office, and the Student Affairs Office through PolyU Connect.

question: Where should I check for messages about study and registration?
What platform should I regularly check for messages about study and registration?
data.answer: You are advised to check for messages in your PolyU Connect Email account regularly.

question: What should students keep updated during their study?
How can students update their contact information?
Why is it important for students to update their correspondence address?
data.answer: Students should keep their residential/correspondence address and mobile number updated. They can update their contact information directly via eStudent. It is important to update the correspondence address so that relevant university officers can reach the next of kin in case of emergencies.

question: Where can students update their contact information?
In case of emergencies, who will be contacted if the student is under 18?
What communication methods may the University use to contact students?
data.answer: Students can update their contact information directly via eStudent. In case of emergencies and if the student is under 18, the next of kin (parents/guardian) will be contacted. The University may contact students by phone, SMS, or post as necessary.

question: For students living away from home, what is important to update?
Why is updating contact information crucial for student-hostel residents?
How can students update their student records in the University?
data.answer: For students living away from home, it is important to update their correspondence address. Updating contact information is crucial for student-hostel residents so that relevant university officers can reach their next of kin in emergencies. Students can update their student records in the University by keeping their residential/correspondence address and mobile number updated.

question: Where can students update their information?
Is there a limit to the duration during which students can update their information?
How can students access the eStudent system?
data.answer: Students can update their information directly on the web during their study and up to their graduation and completion of the university congregation ceremony. There is no specific limit mentioned. Students can access the eStudent system by logging in at http://www.polyu.edu.hk/student.

question: What can students view online in eStudent?
When is a hard copy of Form AR1 required?
What information requires a hard copy for amendment?
data.answer: Students can view their personal particulars online in eStudent. A hard copy of Form AR1 is required for the amendment of name, date of birth, HKID card/Passport/Mainland ID card No., nationality, or gender. The hard copy must be accompanied by the original and a copy of relevant supporting document(s).

question: What happens to the information of a graduate/leaver after an amendment?
Is there a specific form for amending certain information?
What documents are required for amending name, date of birth, or gender?
data.answer: No update will be made to the information of a graduate/leaver after an amendment. Form AR1 is required for amending certain information like name, date of birth, HKID card/Passport/Mainland ID card No., nationality, or gender. The application/supporting document(s) for the amendment will be kept in the student's record.

question: What specifies the normal duration for completion of a program?
Where can you find the normal duration for completion of a program?
In what document is the normal duration for completion mentioned?
data.answer: The normal duration for completion of a program is specified in the Programme Requirement Document, which is issued by the Department at the commencement of the study.

question: When will you receive the Programme Requirement Document?
At what point is the Programme Requirement Document issued?
When does the Department issue the Programme Requirement Document?
data.answer: The Programme Requirement Document will be issued to you by your Department at the commencement of your study.

question: What happens if students admitted in or after 2020/21 exceed the normal duration for completion?
Is there a consequence for exceeding the normal duration for completion for students admitted in or after 2020/21?
What is the consequence for students who exceed the normal duration for completion after 2020/21?
data.answer: Students admitted in or after 2020/21 will be de-registered from the program if they exceed the normal duration for completion, unless prior approval for 'Extension of Study Duration' has been obtained from relevant authorities.

question: Is there an exception for students admitted in or after 2020/21 who exceed the normal duration for completion?
What is the condition for not being de-registered for students admitted in or after 2020/21 who exceed the normal duration for completion?
Under what circumstance will students admitted in or after 2020/21 not be de-registered for exceeding the normal duration for completion?
data.answer: Students admitted in or after 2020/21 will not be de-registered for exceeding the normal duration for completion if they obtain prior approval for 'Extension of Study Duration' from relevant authorities.

question: What is the maximum period allowed for students to register on a program?
How long can students register on a program?
What is the duration limit for student registration on a program?
data.answer: The maximum period allowed for students to register on a program is normally twice the normal duration and must not exceed eight years.

question: Where is the stipulated maximum period of registration mentioned?
In which document is the maximum period of registration specified?
What document contains information about the maximum period of registration?
data.answer: The stipulated maximum period of registration is mentioned in the individual Programme Requirement Document.

question: Does the fact that a student's maximum period of registration has not expired guarantee their continued status as a student?
Is the expiration of the maximum period of registration the only factor in determining a student's status?
Is the sole basis for a student's continued status the non-expiration of their maximum period of registration?
data.answer: No, the fact that a student's maximum period of registration has not expired by itself does not entitle them to remain as a student of the University.

question: Under what circumstance does a student's registration lapse?
In what situation will a student's registration no longer be possible?
What leads to the lapse of a student's registration?
data.answer: A student's registration shall lapse if it is no longer possible for him/her to obtain the designated award within the maximum period of registration.

question: What should I do if you need to be absent from class temporarily during the academic year?
How can I obtain approval for being absent from class temporarily?
What form should I submit to obtain approval for temporary absence from class?
data.answer: If you need to be absent from class for a temporary period during the academic year, you must obtain approval from the Head of Department concerned by submitting Form AR8.

question: Is attendance in classes allowed if I am infected by contagious diseases?
What should I do if you are infected by contagious diseases in relation to attending classes?
Is it recommended to attend classes if you are infected by contagious diseases?
data.answer: You should not attend classes if you are infected by contagious diseases.

question: Is the granting of leave of absence automatic?
What should I keep in mind about the granting of leave of absence?
Is there a specific process for the granting of leave of absence?
data.answer: The granting of leave of absence is not automatic. All applications should be made as early as possible before the leave is taken. The department concerned will inform you of the approval, or otherwise, of your application.

question: What should I do if I am absent from an examination due to sickness or other circumstances beyond your control?
To whom should I apply if I am absent from an examination?
Is there a process for applying for absence from an examination due to sickness or other circumstances?
data.answer: If you are absent from an examination owing to sickness or other circumstances beyond your control, you have to apply to the Head of Department offering the subject with supporting documents (please also refer to section 6H on 'Late Assessment').

question: What happens if I enroll concurrently in two full-time programs?
Is it allowed to enroll in two full-time programs simultaneously?
What are the consequences of enrolling in two full-time programs without approval?
data.answer: Failure to obtain written approval will result in discontinuation of your study at PolyU and the tuition fees paid for the programme(s) will not be refunded.

question: Can I enroll in a full-time program and a part-time program simultaneously?
Is approval required for enrolling in a full-time and a part-time program together?
How should I proceed if I want to enroll in a full-time and a part-time program?
data.answer: For enrolling on a full-time programme and a part-time programme, or on more than one part-time programme leading to any formal award, including those offered by another institution, you are required to obtain approval from the PolyU Head(s) of Department concerned prior to enrolment.

question: Where can I obtain the application form for concurrent enrollment?
What is Form AR38 used for in the context of concurrent enrollment?
How can I apply for concurrent enrollment at PolyU?
data.answer: Those who wish to apply for concurrent enrolment should download an application for concurrent enrolment (Form AR38) or get a copy at the Academic Registry Service Centre. Please return the form to the Academic Registry before registration on the programme(s) concerned.

question: Is the University responsible for making special timetable arrangements for students with concurrent enrolment?
What should students with concurrent enrolment note regarding class and examination timetables?
Are special timetable arrangements made for students with clashes in class and examination timetables?
data.answer: Students who have been granted approval for concurrent enrolment should note that the University is not responsible for making special timetable arrangements in case of clashes in class and examination timetables.

question: Under what circumstances can I apply for deferment of study?
Are there specific conditions for applying for deferment of study?
What constitutes a genuine need for deferment of study?
data.answer: You may apply for deferment of study if you have a genuine need to do so, such as prolonged illness or being posted to work outside Hong Kong.

question: Who is eligible to apply for deferment of study?
Can all students apply for deferment of study?
Are there any restrictions on applying for deferment of study?
data.answer: Applications from students who have not yet completed the first year of a full-time programme will be considered only under exceptional circumstances.

question: How is the deferment period counted towards the total period of registration?
Does the deferment period count towards the maximum period of registration for students admitted in or before 2019/20?
Is the deferment period included in the total registration period?
data.answer: The deferment period will not be counted towards the total period of registration (or maximum period of registration for students admitted in or before 2019/20).

question: How can I submit an application for deferment of study?
Where should I send my application for deferment of study?
Is there a specific platform for submitting applications for deferment of study?
data.answer: You are required to submit an application for deferment of study via eStudent to the programme offering department.

question: How will I be notified of the result of my deferment application?
What is the expected timeframe for receiving the result of a deferment application?
In what form will I receive the result of my deferment application?
data.answer: You will be informed of the result of your application in writing or via email by the department normally within three weeks from the date of application.

question: What is the requirement for processing an application for deferment after the start of a semester?
Is settling outstanding tuition fees necessary for processing a deferment application submitted after the semester begins?
What should I do if I want to defer my study after the semester has started?
data.answer: It is necessary for you to settle all the outstanding tuition fees and/or other fees in order to have your application for deferment processed if the application is submitted after the start of a semester.

question: Are all fees paid refundable and transferable?
Is there any refund for fees paid if I defer my study?
What is the refund policy for tuition fees in case of deferment for new students on UGC-funded programmes?
data.answer: All fees paid are non-refundable and non-transferable. However, new students enrolled on UGC-funded programmes who apply for deferment of study before the commencement of the relevant semester will be eligible for a refund of the tuition fee paid for that semester after deducting an initial fee (of HK$5,000 for local students and HK$15,000 for non-local students).

question: Is there a waiver for the deduction of the initial fee for current students applying for deferment?
Do current students need to pay the initial fee when applying for deferment?
Are current students subject to the deduction of the initial fee when deferring their study?
data.answer: The deduction of such fee will, however, be waived for current students.

question: Will students approved for deferment have access to campus facilities and services?
Are students with approved deferment eligible for accessing campus facilities/services?
What happens to the campus facility and service access for students with approved deferment?
data.answer: Students approved for deferment of study will normally not be eligible to access the campus facilities/services. Students can check for further details from the relevant service providing units.

question: How can I retain my study place if I choose not to defer but still want to take a break from subjects?
What is 'Zero Subject Enrolment and Retention of Study Place' in Section 4I?
What should I do if I want to retain my study place but not enroll in any subjects?
data.answer: Alternatively, you may apply for zero subject enrolment to retain your study place. (Please also refer to section 4I on “Zero Subject Enrolment and Retention of Study Place”.)

question: What can students who have been approved for deferment of study retain for future use?
Is it possible to retain the student identity card during a deferment period?
What is the status of the student identity card for those approved for deferment of study?
data.answer: Students who have been approved for deferment of study can retain their student identity card for use upon their resumption of study.

question: What should I do upon the expiry of the deferment period?
What are the advised actions for students after the deferment period ends?
Is there any specific guidance for students when the deferment period concludes?
data.answer: You will be advised to settle the tuition fee and complete the subject registration procedures upon expiry of the deferment period.

question: What should I do if I haven't received notification regarding settling tuition fees and subject registration one week before the semester starts?
Is there a specific time frame for receiving notification about settling fees and subject registration after deferment?
What if I don't receive notification one week before the Semester regarding settling tuition fees and subject registration?
data.answer: If you do not receive such notification one week before the commencement of the Semester, you should enquire at the Academic Registry.

question: What should I do if I do not wish to take any subject in a semester?
How can I retain my study place if I don't want to enroll in any subjects?
When should I submit my application for zero subject enrolment to retain my study place?
data.answer: If you do not wish to take any subject in a semester, you must seek approval from your department to retain your study place by submitting your application via eStudent before the start of the semester and in any case not later than the end of the add/drop period.

question: What happens if I don't seek approval for zero subject enrolment?
What are the consequences if I fail to retain my study place by seeking approval for zero subject enrolment?
What is the outcome if I don't apply for zero subject enrolment approval?
data.answer: Otherwise, your student status with the University will be withdrawn.

question: How will the semesters with zero subject enrolment be counted?
Will the semesters in which I take zero subjects be included in the total period of registration?
Do semesters with zero subject enrolment count towards the maximum period of registration?
data.answer: Unless otherwise approved, the semesters during which you are allowed to take zero subjects will be counted towards the total period of registration for the programme concerned.

question: When can I expect to receive the result notification after applying for zero subject enrolment?
How long does it take to get the result notification after applying for zero subject enrolment?
Within what timeframe will I receive the result notification for zero subject enrolment?
data.answer: You will receive result notification from the department normally within two weeks.

question: Can I still use campus facilities if I have been approved for zero subject enrolment?
Are students with zero subject enrolment approval allowed to use campus facilities?
Do I have access to library facilities if I am approved for zero subject enrolment?
data.answer: Students who have been approved for zero subject enrolment are allowed to continue using campus facilities, including library facilities.

question: How much is the fee for retaining my study place with zero subject enrolment?
What is the cost for keeping my study place with zero subject enrolment?
How much will I be charged for retaining my study place if I don't enroll in any subjects?
data.answer: A fee of HK$2,105 per semester for retention of study place will be charged.

question: What circumstances will be considered for a transfer of study?
Under what conditions is the transfer of study allowed?
In what situations is the transfer of study considered?
data.answer: Transfer of study will only be considered in exceptional circumstances.

question: When will new students be considered for transfer to another programme?
At what point can a new student apply for a transfer to another program?
In which semester can a new student request a transfer to another program?
data.answer: New students will only be considered for transfer to another programme starting from their second semester of registration.

question: What is the policy regarding transfer for UGC-funded program students?
For UGC-funded program students, what should be submitted for a transfer of study?
What application should UGC-funded program students submit if they want to transfer to a similar level program at PolyU?
data.answer: If you are registered in a UGC-funded programme and wish to transfer to another PolyU UGC-funded programme of the same level of award, you should submit an application for transfer of study.

question: Who is not allowed to submit a further application for transfer of study to full-time programs within PolyU?
Are current Higher Diploma students who applied via JUPAS allowed to submit a transfer of study application?
In what situation are JUPAS applicants from Higher Diploma programs restricted from applying for transfer of study?
data.answer: Current Higher Diploma students who have chosen to submit an application via JUPAS are not allowed to submit a further application for transfer of study to full-time programs within PolyU.

question: Under what conditions will applications for transfer of study be considered?
What is required for transfer of study applications to be considered?
What is the key factor for the consideration of transfer of study applications?
data.answer: Applications for transfer of study can only be considered subject to availability of places.

question: How should applications for transfer of study be submitted?
What is the required form for transfer of study applications?
What form should be used for submitting transfer of study applications?
data.answer: Applications for transfer of study should be made via Form AR25.

question: What is the definition of full-time students?
How are full-time students classified?
What is expected from students on full-time programmes?
data.answer: Students enrolled on full-time programmes are classified as full-time students. They are expected to devote the whole of their time to study even though they may or may not follow the specified progression pattern.

question: What should I do if I want to take a study load of less than 9 credits in a semester as a full-time student?
How can I request to take fewer than 9 credits in a semester as a full-time student?
What is the process for seeking approval to take a reduced study load as a full-time student?
data.answer: Students on full-time programmes who wish to take a study load of less than 9 credits in a semester will have to seek prior approval from their department by submitting an application via Form AR121 before the end of the add/drop period.

question: What options do students admitted in or before 2017/18 have if they want to take a study load of less than 9 credits?
How can students admitted in or before 2017/18 pay credit fees if they take fewer than 9 credits?
What is the process for students admitted in or before 2017/18 to pay credit fees for a reduced study load?
data.answer: Students admitted in or before 2017/18 will be given the option to pay credit fees upon the approval of taking a study load of less than 9 credits. If you wish to exercise this option, you are required to apply via Form AR121 and you need to pay tuition fee for subject(s) you will be taking in the Summer Term of that academic year.

question: What is the requirement for students admitted in or after 2018/19 to UGC-funded programmes regarding fees?
How are fees structured for students admitted in or after 2018/19 to UGC-funded programmes?
Do students admitted in or after 2018/19 have to pay credit fees based on the number of credits they take?
data.answer: Students admitted in or after 2018/19 to UGC-funded programmes are required to pay a flat fee during the normal duration of the programme, regardless of the number of credits registered in a semester. Students studying beyond the normal duration also have to pay a flat fee if they take 9 or more credits per semester. Students who take less than 9 credits per semester will pay the credit fees.

question: What is the classification for students with a study load of less than 9 credits in a semester?
How are students enrolling in part-time, distance learning, online, and mixed-mode programs classified?
Who is considered a part-time student?
data.answer: Part-time students

question: What is the study load threshold for classifying students as part-time?
How many credits in a semester define a part-time student?
When is a student considered part-time?
data.answer: Less than 9 credits in a semester

question: What types of programs do part-time students enroll in?
Which study modes are associated with part-time student classification?
For what kind of programs are students considered part-time?
data.answer: Part-time, distance learning, online, and mixed-mode programs

question: Do part-time students have to pay credit fees?
What is the fee structure for part-time students?
Is there a fee for part-time students?
data.answer: Yes, all part-time students will pay credit fees.

question: Is there an exception to the 9-credit threshold for part-time classification?
Can a student be considered part-time with more than 9 credits?
Under what circumstances can a student with more than 9 credits be part-time?
data.answer: Unless otherwise approved by the department concerned

question: Can mixed-mode students choose between full-time and part-time study loads?
What study loads are available for mixed-mode students?
Is there flexibility in the study load for mixed-mode students?
data.answer: They may take up a full-time or part-time study load.

question: When can mixed-mode students attend classes?
What are the possible class attendance times for mixed-mode students?
Is there a specific time for classes for mixed-mode students?
data.answer: In the daytime, in the evening, or a combination of both.

question: Where can the class attendance pattern for mixed-mode programs be found?
Is the class attendance pattern specified for mixed-mode students?
In what documents are the details of class attendance specified for mixed-mode programs?
data.answer: In the admission/programme documents.

question: When will mixed-mode students be given full-time status in a semester?
Under what condition will mixed-mode students be considered full-time?
What study load qualifies mixed-mode students for full-time status?
data.answer: If they take subjects with a study load reaching the minimum requirement of a full-time student (i.e., 9 credits).

question: In what situations will mixed-mode students be given part-time status?
Under what circumstances do mixed-mode students have part-time status?
When will mixed-mode students be considered part-time?
data.answer: Otherwise, they will be given part-time status unless approved otherwise by the department concerned to retain a full-time status.

question: What do self-paced students need to do if they want to study at their own pace?
How can I study at my own pace instead of following the specified progression pattern?
What is the process for becoming a self-paced student?
data.answer: Self-paced students need to seek approval from the department by completing Form AR114 before the commencement of the semester concerned.

question: Who are considered self-paced students?
When can I become a self-paced student?
What qualifies someone to be a self-paced student?
data.answer: Self-paced students are those who have been given approval by their department not to follow the specified progression pattern or those registered on programs which do not have any specified progression patterns.

question: How long will I remain a self-paced student once approved?
Is there a time limit for being a self-paced student?
What is the duration of being a self-paced student?
data.answer: Once you are approved to become self-paced, you will remain as a self-paced student throughout your entire study.

question: What should I do as a self-paced student?
How should I approach studying as a self-paced student?
What is the responsibility of a self-paced student?
data.answer: Self-paced students should study the programme requirements carefully, consult the departmental academic advisors, and perform subject registration according to the schedule announced by the Academic Registry.

question: What is emphasized for self-paced students?
What is expected of self-paced students regarding their progress?
What is the key responsibility of self-paced students?
data.answer: It is your responsibility to monitor your progress of study and to ensure that the programme requirements are completed within the maximum period of registration (for students admitted in or before 2019/20)/normal duration (for students admitted in or after 2020/21) of your programme.

question: What is a graduand?
Define graduand.
Who are classified as graduands?
data.answer: For those who have satisfied all the academic requirements but have not been conferred the academic awards, they are classified as Graduands.

question: What do graduands need to comply with?
Until when do graduands need to comply with the Rules and Regulations of a student?
data.answer: Graduands need to comply with the Rules and Regulations of a student until they have graduated.

question: What is the procedure for discontinuing study at the University?
How can I discontinue my study at the University?
data.answer: If you wish to discontinue your study at the University before completing your programme, it is necessary for you to complete the withdrawal procedure via eStudent.

question: Will fees be refunded if I withdraw during the semester?
What happens to fees paid for the semester if I withdraw?
data.answer: Fees paid for the semester in which you are studying will not be refunded.

question: When should applications for withdrawal be submitted for the current semester?
Is there a deadline for submitting applications for withdrawal for the current semester?
data.answer: Applications for withdrawal of study for the current semester must be submitted before the commencement of the examination period.

question: What happens if I submit an application for withdrawal after the commencement of the examination period?
Will late applications for withdrawal be processed?
data.answer: Applications submitted after the commencement of the examination period will not be processed.

question: When should applications for withdrawal for the following academic year/semester be submitted?
Is there a deadline for submitting applications for withdrawal for the next academic year/semester?
data.answer: Applications for withdrawal of study for the following academic year/semester should be submitted before the commencement of that academic year/semester.

question: What outstanding matters might hinder the processing of your application?
List some outstanding matters that need to be cleared for application processing.
data.answer: Your application will not be processed if you have not cleared outstanding matters with the various departments/offices concerned, such as settling outstanding fees/fines and Library loans and clearing your locker provided by the Student Affairs Office.

question: How will you be informed of the result of your application?
Within what timeframe will you typically receive information about your application result?
data.answer: The relevant department will inform you in writing or via email of the result of your application, normally within three weeks after you have cleared all the outstanding items as mentioned above.

question: What is the eligibility criterion for a refund of caution money upon official withdrawal?
Under what condition will you be eligible for the refund of caution money?
data.answer: Upon confirmation of your official withdrawal, you will be eligible for the refund of the caution money paid if you have no outstanding debts to the University.

question: Are all fees paid refundable?
Under what circumstances are fees non-refundable?
data.answer: All fees paid are non-refundable and non-transferable.

question: Who is eligible for a refund of tuition fee for a semester before the commencement?
What is the condition for refund eligibility for new students enrolled in UGC-funded programmes?
data.answer: New students enrolled on UGC-funded programmes who apply for withdrawal of study before the commencement of the relevant semester will be eligible for a refund of the tuition fee paid for that semester after deducting an initial fee.

question: What happens if you discontinue your study without completing proper withdrawal procedures?
How will discontinuing study without proper withdrawal procedures affect the caution money paid at first registration?
data.answer: If you discontinue your study at the University without completing proper withdrawal procedures, you will be regarded as having unofficially withdrawn and the caution money paid at first registration will be confiscated.

question: What happens if you discontinue your study without following proper procedures?
How is discontinuation of study without official withdrawal treated?
data.answer: If you discontinue your study without following the proper procedures for official withdrawal, you will be regarded as having given up your study at the University.

question: What are the consequences of discontinuing study without proper procedures?
Will you be eligible for a refund if you discontinue without following the proper procedures?
data.answer: In this case, you will not be eligible for the refund of caution money.

question: Can you be considered for re-admission if you discontinue without proper procedures?
What is the status for re-admission after discontinuation without official withdrawal?
data.answer: You shall not be considered for re-admission to the same scheme/programme/stream (sub-code) in the following academic year.

question: What happens if I get de-registered due to academic failure?
Can I be considered for re-admission if I've been de-registered for academic reasons?
Is re-admission possible after being de-registered due to academic failure?
data.answer: Students who have been de-registered on grounds of academic failure shall not be considered for re-admission to the same scheme/programme/stream (sub-code) in the following academic year.

question: How can I apply for a Minor?
When should I submit my application for a Minor?
What are the eligibility criteria for enrolling in a Minor?
Can I apply for a Minor in the senior year of my program?
data.answer: Students interested in a Minor must submit their application via the Major-offering department and obtain approval from the Minor-offering department, at the start of the second year of study during the designated application period. No late applications will be considered. To be eligible for enrolment in a Minor, a student must have a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or above at the time of application for Minor enrolment. The Minor-offering department may set a quota and additional admission requirements apart from the above GPA requirement. Students admitted to the advanced stage of a programme on senior year status and those admitted to an articulation degree programme will not be given the option to study for a Minor. For students who are admitted on the basis of advanced standing, the programme offering department will decide whether they will be given the option to study a Minor at the time of admission, based on individual merits.

question: What is the process for students who want to withdraw from a Minor?
How can students withdraw from a Minor?
When should students seek approval to withdraw from a Minor?
data.answer: Students who wish to withdraw from a Minor need to seek approval from the Minor-offering department, prior to the end of the add/drop period of the last semester of study.

question: Where can students find the list of Minors?
What is the path to access the list of Minors?
Can you guide me on where to find information about Minors?
data.answer: Students can refer to the list of Minors at AR Website > Students in Taught Programmes > Registration Information > Double Major/Minor Study/List of Minors.

question: How many credits can be transferred for a Minor from institutions outside the university?
What is the limit for credit transfer from approved institutions outside the university for a Minor?
Can you tell me the maximum number of credits that can be transferred for a Minor from external institutions?
data.answer: Credit transfer can be given for not more than 9 credits of a Minor programme if the previous credits were earned from approved institutions outside of the university.

question: How many credits of a Minor programme can be transferred if earned from PolyU programmes?
What is the credit transfer limit for a Minor if the previous credits were earned from PolyU programmes?
Can you provide information on credit transfer for a Minor from PolyU programmes?
data.answer: Credit transfer can be given for not more than 12 credits of a Minor programme if the previous credits were earned from programmes offered by PolyU.

question: When should students apply for graduation?
At what point should students submit their graduation application?
What is the recommended time for students to apply for graduation?
data.answer: Students concerned are required to apply for graduation to enable calculation of a proper GPA for award classification determination, in the semester in which they are expected to fulfil all their graduation requirements, and after the add/drop period for that semester.

question: What happens if a student is confirmed eligible to graduate or leaves the University?
Can you explain the consequences if a student is confirmed eligible to graduate or leaves the University?
What occurs when a student is confirmed eligible to graduate or decides to leave the University?
data.answer: Upon confirmation of eligibility to graduate or leaving the University, registration on subjects (including the follow-on term of consecutive subjects) in the following semester/Summer Term will be nullified and removed.

question: What is the typical duration for completing a Double Major program?
How long does it usually take to finish a Double Major?
Is there a standard timeframe for completing a Double Major?
data.answer: Students intending to complete a Double Major typically require a longer normal duration for completion of the programme (i.e. beyond four/five years).

question: What additional requirement do students pursuing a Double Major have?
Are there any extra credits needed for a Double Major?
Do Double Major students need to fulfill any special credit requirements?
data.answer: Students intending to complete a Double Major typically require a longer normal duration for completion of the programme and to take extra credits on a self-financed basis (i.e. higher tuition fee).

question: What determines the number of credits needed for a Double Major?
How is the credit requirement for a Double Major determined?
Is there a fixed number of credits for a Double Major?
data.answer: The actual number of credits required for getting a Double Major depends on the level of commonality between the two Majors.

question: When can students interested in a Second Major submit their applications?
At what point in their studies can students apply for a Second Major?
Is there a specific time when students can apply for a Second Major?
data.answer: Students interested in taking a Second Major should first obtain approval from the host department of the First Major. They can then submit their applications to the host department of the Second Major from their second year of study.

question: What is the GPA requirement for consideration in Second Major study enrollment?
Is there a minimum GPA required for Second Major study?
Who is eligible for Second Major study enrollment?
data.answer: Only students with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or above can be considered for Second Major study enrollment. Departments can, however, stipulate a higher GPA requirement for entry to the Second Major.

question: What is expected of students once they are enrolled in a Second Major?
What do students need to do after being accepted into a Second Major?
Are there any obligations for students in a Second Major?
data.answer: Once enrolled, students are expected to complete the Second Major as part of their graduation requirements.

question: How can students withdraw from a Second Major?
What is the process for officially withdrawing from a Second Major?
Are there any formalities for withdrawing from a Second Major?
data.answer: Students who wish to withdraw from a Second Major need to apply for approval officially from the host department of the Second Major before the end of the add/drop period of the last semester of study.

question: How can I apply for a Secondary Major?
What is the designated application period for a Secondary Major?
When can I submit a late application for a Secondary Major?
data.answer: Students admitted in or after 2022/23 interested in a Secondary Major should submit their application and obtain approval from the Major-offering department during the designated application period. Late applications submitted before the commencement of the second year of study will be considered case-by-case.

question: Who is eligible for consideration for Secondary Major enrollment?
What GPA is required for Secondary Major enrollment?
Can I be considered for Secondary Major enrollment if my GPA is below 2.70?
data.answer: Only students with a Cumulative GPA of 2.70 or above after Semester Two of Year One may be considered for Secondary Major enrollment. Students with a GPA below 2.70 will not be considered.

question: Is it possible to have more than one Secondary Major?
Can I take both a Major and a Secondary Major?
What is the limit on the number of Secondary Majors a student can have?
data.answer: Each student may take not more than one Secondary Major. If deemed appropriate by the Major-offering department, students are allowed to take a Major with a Secondary Major and a Minor.

question: What additional criteria may the Secondary Major-offering department stipulate for admission?
Are there any specific requirements set by the Secondary Major department for admission?
Can the Secondary Major department set additional criteria for enrollment?
data.answer: The Secondary Major-offering department may stipulate additional selection criteria for admission.

question: What is the eligibility for studying a Secondary Major?
Are there any exceptions to studying a Secondary Major?
Who decides if students admitted on senior year status can pursue a Secondary Major?
data.answer: Students admitted to the advanced stage of a programme on senior year status and those admitted to an articulation degree programme will normally not be given the option to study for a Secondary Major. For students who are admitted on the basis of advanced standing, the programme offering department will decide whether they will be given the option to study a Secondary Major at the time of admission, based on individual merits.

question: What is the expectation for students enrolled in a Secondary Major?
Is there a time limit for completing Major and Secondary Major studies?
What if a student wants to withdraw from a Secondary Major?
data.answer: Students who have enrolled in a Secondary Major are expected to complete their Major and Secondary Major studies within the normal duration of the Major programme. Students who wish to withdraw from a Secondary Major need to seek approval from the Major-offering department, prior to the end of the add/drop period of the last semester of study.

question: What should I check to ensure my subject registration fulfills the graduation requirements?
What is my responsibility regarding subject registration and graduation requirements?
Where can I find information about subject prerequisites and progression patterns for my program?
data.answer: It is your responsibility to check if your subject registration will fulfill the graduation requirements. You should study the Programme Requirement Document, the subject prerequisite, co-requisite and exclusion requirements and the specified progression pattern, if any, of your programme before subject registration.

question: What is the specified progression pattern?
How can I complete the program within the normal duration?
Why is it important to follow the specified progression pattern?
data.answer: The specified progression pattern is the sequence of subject selections recommended by your department. By following this sequence, you can complete the programme within the normal duration.

question: What should I do if I wish to deviate from the specified progression pattern?
How can I change my status to 'self-paced' in subject registration?
Is there a process for seeking approval to deviate from the specified progression pattern?
data.answer: If you wish to deviate from the specified progression pattern, you need to seek approval from your department to change your status to 'self-paced' by completing Form AR114.

question: What is the normal study load in a semester?
How many credits can a student take in a semester?
What is the maximum study load in a semester without departmental approval?
data.answer: The normal study load is 15 credits in a semester. The University has a limit on the maximum study load that a student can take in a semester, which is 21 credits, unless the subjects have been pre-assigned by the department or exceptional approval is given by the Head of the programme offering department.

question: How are students classified if the programme does not have a specified progression pattern?
What is the classification for self-paced students?
Who are considered self-paced students?
data.answer: Students enrolled in programmes without specified progression patterns will be classified as self-paced students.

question: What is the requirement for self-paced students regarding program completion?
How should self-paced students plan their study?
What is the maximum period of registration for self-paced students admitted in or before 2019/20?
data.answer: Self-paced students need to plan their own study and complete the programme requirements within the maximum period of registration (for students admitted in or before 2019/20)/normal duration (for students admitted in or after 2020/21) of the programme.

question: What should students on academic probation do to ensure academic performance?
Who should students on academic probation consult regarding study loads?
What is the recommended study load for students on academic probation?
data.answer: To ensure academic performance, students on academic probation are required to seek academic advice on their study loads and subjects to be taken. These students will normally be required to take a study load of not more than 15 credits (for details, please refer to section 6C on “Academic Probation”).

question: What subjects can I select on a semester basis?
How can I choose subjects each semester?
In which system can I register for subjects each semester?
data.answer: You can select other subjects on a semester basis through the online subject registration system via eStudent according to the schedule announced by the Academic Registry.

question: Should I make changes to subjects assigned to me by departments?
Is it advisable to modify the subjects pre-assigned by departments without consultation?
What should I do if I want to make changes to the subjects pre-assigned by my department?
data.answer: You are not advised to make any changes to subjects assigned to you by departments without consulting your department/Academic Advisor.

question: Do I need approval to drop subjects pre-assigned by my department?
What is the process for dropping subjects pre-assigned by the department?
Should I obtain approval to drop subjects pre-assigned by my department?
