data.answer: Students enrolled on undergraduate degree programmes and Higher Diploma programmes need to obtain prior approval from their Departments should they have genuine needs to drop subjects pre-assigned/assigned by their Departments.

question: When can I select General University Requirements (GUR) subjects?
Is there a specific semester for choosing GUR subjects?
Can I choose GUR subjects at any time before graduation?
data.answer: Students can select General University Requirements (GUR) subjects in any semester before graduation unless otherwise specified in the Programme Requirement Document.

question: How are work-integrated studies arranged?
Who arranges the work-integrated studies?
Where can I find details about work-integrated studies arrangements?
data.answer: The work-integrated studies are arranged either by Departments or the Student Affairs Office (SAO). Details are set out in the Programme Requirement Document.

question: What happens if I fail to complete subject registration according to schedule and haven't applied for deferment or zero subject enrolment?
What are the consequences if subject registration is not completed according to schedule and deferment or zero subject enrolment is not applied?
What happens if I miss the subject registration deadline and don't apply for deferment or zero subject enrolment?
data.answer: Students who fail to complete subject registration according to schedule and have not applied for deferment or zero subject enrolment will be subject to the removal of their registration and student status with the University (for details, please refer to sections 4H & 4I on “Deferment of Study” and “Zero Subject Enrolment”).

question: When is the class timetable usually released for Semester One?
When can I expect the release of the class timetable for Semester Two?
What is the usual release timeframe for the class timetable for Summer Term?
data.answer: The class timetable will normally be released around late July for Semester One, around mid-December for Semester Two, and around late February for Summer Term via eStudent to facilitate relevant subject registration of students.

question: Who has the final authority to decide on the subject selection of students?
Which department has the authority to decide on the subject selection of its students?
Who determines the subject selection for students?
data.answer: The programme offering department has the final authority to decide on the subject selection of its students.

question: Under what circumstances can a department cancel the offering of a subject?
What gives a department the right to cancel the offering of a subject?
In what situations can a department decide to cancel the offering of a subject?
data.answer: Departments also have the right to cancel the offering of a subject if the class enrolment is too small. You will be advised to take other replacement subjects/classes in case of cancellation.

question: When are students required to graduate?
What is the expectation regarding graduation for students?
When should students aim to graduate?
data.answer: Students are required to graduate as soon as they satisfy the graduation requirement.

question: What happens upon confirmation of eligibility to graduate or leaving the University?
What happens to subject registration upon confirmation of eligibility to graduate or leaving the University?
What is the procedure for subject registration after confirmation of eligibility to graduate or leaving the University?
data.answer: Upon confirmation of eligibility to graduate or leaving the University, registration for subjects (including the follow-on term of consecutive subjects) in the following semester/Summer Term will be nullified and removed from record.

question: What is the minimum credit requirement for eligibility for a PolyU award?
How much of the normal credit requirement should students complete to be eligible for a PolyU award?
data.answer: All students should complete at least one third of the normal credit requirement to be eligible for a PolyU award.

question: What can I do if I believe my previous study is relevant to my current programme?
Is there a process for getting credit for my previous study in my current programme?
data.answer: If you consider your previous study is relevant to your current programme, you may apply for subject exemption or credit transfer.

question: What should I do if I want to be exempted from certain subjects?
How can I avoid taking specific subjects in my program?
Is there a way to skip certain subjects in my program?
data.answer: You may be granted exemption from taking certain subjects if you have successfully completed similar subjects in another programme.

question: Are the credits from the exempted subject counted towards my program's credit requirements?
Do the credits from the exempted subject contribute to my overall credit count?
Will the credits from the exempted subject satisfy the credit requirements of my program?
data.answer: The credits associated with the exempted subject will not be counted for satisfying the credit requirements of your programme.

question: Who should I consult regarding subject exemptions?
Where can I get information about exempting subjects in my program?
Is there someone specific I should talk to about subject exemptions?
data.answer: You should consult your department for guidance on subject exemptions.

question: What should I do after being granted exemption for a subject?
How can I replace an exempted subject in my program?
Is there a process for substituting an exempted subject with another?
data.answer: You should consult your department and take another subject in place of the exempted one.

question: When should I submit an application for credit transfer?
At what point in my enrollment should I apply for credit transfer?
Is there a specific time frame for submitting a credit transfer application?
data.answer: You should submit an application for credit transfer upon your initial enrollment in the program or before the end of the add/drop period of the first semester of your first year of study.

question: What happens if I submit a credit transfer application late?
Will my late credit transfer application be considered?
Is there a deadline for credit transfer applications?
data.answer: Late applications may not be considered.

question: Is there a fee for credit transfer?
Do I need to pay for a credit transfer application?
Are there any charges associated with credit transfers?
data.answer: For students whose tuition fees are charged by credits, a credit transfer fee will be charged.

question: How long is the validity period for subject credits?
What is the time limit for using earned subject credits?
When do subject credits expire?
data.answer: The validity period of subject credits earned is eight years from the year of attainment unless otherwise specified by the Department responsible for the content of the subject.

question: When do credits earned from previous studies become invalid?
Is there a specific time when credits from previous studies expire?
Do credits earned in previous studies have a validity period?
data.answer: Credits earned from previous studies should remain valid at the time when the student applies for the transfer of credits.

question: What is the maximum limit for credit transfer if the credits are from PolyU?
How many credits can be transferred if they are from PolyU?
Is there a limit to the credits transferred from PolyU?
data.answer: The total credits transferred from PolyU should not exceed 67% of the required credits for the award.

question: What is the limit on transferred credits if they are from other institutions?
Can you exceed 50% of required credits when transferring from other institutions?
How many credits can be transferred if gained from other institutions?
data.answer: The total credits transferred from other institutions should not exceed 50% of the required credits for the award.

question: If both PolyU and other institutions' credits are transferred, what is the limit?
Can you transfer more than 50% of required credits if both types are transferred?
What is the maximum percentage of credits allowed if both PolyU and other institutions' credits are transferred?
data.answer: In case both types of credits are transferred, not more than 50% of the required number of credits for the academic award may be transferred.

question: Are grades given for transferred credits?
Do transferred credits receive grades?
Is there a grading system for transferred credits?
data.answer: Grades may or may not be given for the transferred credits.

question: Do transferred credits count towards satisfying award requirements?
Are transferred credits considered for meeting award requirements?
Is there any contribution of transferred credits to meeting award requirements?
data.answer: All credits transferred will be counted for satisfying the award requirements.

question: Can transferred credits be used for more than one degree?
Do transferred credits count for multiple degrees?
Is there a restriction on using transferred credits for multiple degrees?
data.answer: Transferred credits are normally not counted for meeting the requirements of more than one degree.

question: What happens if you have an advanced qualification relevant to the program?
Can you take fewer credits if you have an advanced qualification?
Is there any flexibility in the credit requirements for those with advanced qualifications?
data.answer: If you have an advanced qualification relevant to the program, you may be allowed to take fewer credits than what the program normally requires.

question: Are the credits not required to study counted in credit transfer?
Do credits not required to study contribute to credit transfer?
Is there any impact on credit transfer if some credits are not required to study?
data.answer: When you apply for credit transfer, the credits that you are not required to study will also be counted towards the maximum number of transferred credits.

question: What is the maximum entry credit transfer for UGC-funded degree programs?
How many credits can be transferred for UGC-funded degree programs?
Is there a limit on entry credit transfer for UGC-funded degree programs?
data.answer: Students admitted to a UGC-funded degree program will normally be given entry credit transfer up to a maximum of 25% of the credit requirement for a degree program.

question: What is the maximum percentage of credit transfer allowed for UGC-funded degree programme students?
How much credit transfer can students admitted to a UGC-funded degree programme receive?
Is there a limit to the credit transfer for UGC-funded degree programme students?
data.answer: up to a maximum of 25% of the credit requirement for a degree programme.

question: Do students in Articulation Degree or Senior Year curriculum receive credit transfer for GUR subjects?
How does credit transfer work for students in Articulation Degree or Senior Year curriculum?
Are Articulation Degree or Senior Year curriculum students eligible for credit transfer in required GUR subjects?
data.answer: they will not be given credit transfer for any required GUR subjects, and are required to complete at least 60 credits in order to be eligible for a Bachelor’s award.

question: What should students do when applying for credit transfer of retaken subjects?
How is the grade considered for credit transfer of retaken subjects?
Is there a specific rule for credit transfer of retaken subjects with a carried-over grade?
data.answer: the grade attained in the last attempt should be taken.

question: Are students required to declare anything when applying for credit transfer for subjects taken in other institutions?
What is the declaration requirement for credit transfer of subjects from other institutions?
Is there any specific requirement for students applying for credit transfer from other institutions?
data.answer: Students applying for credit transfer for a subject taken in other institutions are required to declare that the subject grade used for claiming credit transfer was attained in the last attempt of the subject in their previous studies.

question: What happens if a student fails in the last attempt of a retaken subject?
Is credit transfer granted if a student fails in the last attempt of a retaken subject?
Does failing in the last attempt of a retaken subject affect credit transfer?
data.answer: If a student fails in the last attempt of a retaken subject, no credit transfer should be granted, despite the fact that the student may have attained a pass grade for the subject in the earlier attempts.

question: What happens if a student attempts and fails a subject in their current study?
Is credit transfer allowed for subjects attempted and failed in the current study?
Under what circumstances will students not be granted credit transfer for a subject they failed in their current study?
data.answer: Students will not be granted credit transfer for a subject which they have attempted and failed in their current study unless the subject was taken by the student as an exchange-out student in his/her current programme.

question: How can credits be earned through studying during outbound exchange?
What is the process for earning credits during outbound exchange?
Can studying during outbound exchange contribute to earning credits?
data.answer: You can also earn credits through studying during your outbound exchange.

question: What should I do before deciding on subjects for an exchange institution?
Is there a step I should take before selecting subjects for an exchange institution?
How can I ensure credit transfer for subjects at the exchange institution?
data.answer: Before you decide on which subjects to take at the exchange institution, you should seek provisional approval from your programme offering department on the study plan and the possibility of credit transfer for fulfilling the award requirement of your programme by completing Form AR41a.

question: What is the procedure after successfully completing an exchange programme/activity?
How can I apply for credit transfer after completing an exchange programme?
Is there a formal application process for credit transfer after an exchange programme?
data.answer: Upon successful completion of the exchange programme/activity, you need to submit a formal application for credit transfer via eStudent (Form AR41c).

question: Is there a limit to the percentage of total credits transferred for students who received transferred credits from an approved exchange programme?
Can students who received transferred credits from an exchange programme exceed a certain credit limit?
What is the maximum percentage of total credits transferable for students with credits from an approved exchange programme?
data.answer: Students who received transferred credits from an approved exchange programme can exceed the 50% limit of total credits transferred.

question: How can I seek approval for exemption or credit transfer for language subjects?
What is the process for obtaining exemption or credit transfer for language subjects?
Is it possible to get exemption from compulsory language subjects?
Are there any conditions for seeking exemption from compulsory language subjects?
data.answer: You may also seek approval from your department for exemption or credit transfer for language subjects attained in previous study.

question: What steps should I take if I want exemption from compulsory language subjects?
Is there a test for exemption or credit transfer for compulsory language subjects?
How can I demonstrate my proficiency for exemption from language subjects?
data.answer: Students seeking exemption or credit transfer for compulsory language subjects may be required to take a suitable test to demonstrate their level of proficiency.

question: When will credit transfers approved for extenuating circumstances take effect?
Is there a specific time for the approval of credit transfers in extenuating circumstances?
What is the graduation eligibility for students with extenuating circumstances and credit transfers?
data.answer: All credit transfers approved for extenuating circumstances will take effect only in the semester for which they are approved. Such students will only be eligible for graduation at the end of that semester.

question: What should I do if I have failed a subject?
How can I check if I have failed any subject?
Where can I find information about my subject results?
What is the maximum study load per semester?
How many times can I retake a subject?
What happens if I fail a compulsory subject after two retakes?
Are there any additional regulations for retaking certain types of subjects?
How do I retake a failed subject for the first time?
What should I do for the second retake of a failed subject?
Which form should I complete for the second retake, and where should I submit it?
data.answer: Students may only retake a subject which they have failed (i.e. Grade F or S or U). After the announcement of subject results in a semester, you should check whether you have failed any subject via eStudent (please refer to section 6G on “Assessment Results”) and arrange for retaking of the subject during subject registration. Retaking of subjects is with the condition that the maximum study load of 21 credits per semester is not exceeded. The number of retakes of each subject is restricted to a maximum of two. The second retake of a failed subject requires the approval of the Faculty/School Board. Students who have failed a compulsory subject after two retakes will be de-registered. Departments may impose more stringent regulations on the retaking of particular types of subjects, e.g. practicum and clinical placement, and should inform students of such cases, if any. Students can retake a failed subject the first time via eStudent directly during the subject registration period and add/drop period. For a second retake of a failed subject, students should complete form AR160 instead and return it to the programme offering departments to seek approval.

question: What happens when I retake a failed subject?
How is the GPA calculated when retaking a failed subject?
Tell me about the inclusion of grades in GPA for retaken subjects.
data.answer: When you retake a failed subject, only the grade obtained in the final attempt of the retake will be included in the calculation of Grade Point Average (GPA) and GPA for award classification.

question: Will the original grade be considered in GPA calculations when I retake a subject?
Is the original grade included in the GPA for retaken subjects?
What happens to the original grade in GPA calculations when retaking a failed subject?
data.answer: Although the original grade will not be included in the calculation of GPAs, it will be shown in the Transcript of Studies.

question: Where can I find information about retaking failed subjects?
How can I know the requirements for retaking failed subjects?
What should I refer to for information on retaking failed subjects?
data.answer: You should refer to the Programme Requirement Document to ascertain the requirements, in particular for subjects offered in consecutive semesters, for retaking failed subjects, or seek advice from the Department concerned.

question: Do I need to pay for retaking failed subjects?
Are there any charges for retaking subjects?
What is the policy for students paying credit fee when retaking subjects?
data.answer: Students paying credit fee will be charged for the subjects retaken.

question: What should I do if I fail a subject that is a prerequisite for the next semester's follow-on subjects?
How can I check if I have any unqualified subjects?
Where can I find information about unqualified subjects after the finalization of the semester subject results?
data.answer: Upon the finalization of the semester subject results, if you have failed a subject which is a pre-requisite of the follow-on subject(s) in the next semester, the follow-on subject(s) which you enrolled earlier will be removed from your subject registration record, and you will not be qualified for attending classes of these subject(s). You are advised to check the unqualified subjects records, if any, via eStudent [http://www.polyu.edu.hk/student > My Subject Registration > Subject Registration History > Unqualified Subject(s)] to find out whether you have any unqualified subjects after the finalization of subject result of the last semester.

question: How will I know if I have been waived from the pre-requisite requirement for unqualified subjects?
What should I do if my department doesn't grant me a waiver for the pre-requisite requirement but I still want to take the unqualified subject?
Is there a deadline for taking action regarding unqualified subjects after the finalization of subject results?
data.answer: Normally, your program offering department will inform you if you have been waived from the pre-requisite requirement and are allowed to take the unqualified subject. However, in case the department concerned does not grant you the waiver but you still wish to take the unqualified subject, you should approach your department to seek special approval. Alternatively, you can take other subjects in place of the 'unqualified subjects.' You should complete these actions before the end of the add/drop period of the semester concerned.

question: How can I make changes to my subject registration?
Where can I modify my subject registration?
What is the process for adjusting my subjects?
data.answer: If you wish to make changes to your subject registration, you may do so through the add/drop at eStudent during the two-week add/drop period (one week for Summer Term).

question: Is it advisable to modify the subjects pre-assigned to me without consultation?
Should I consult someone before changing the subjects assigned by the department?
Is there any guidance on changing pre-assigned subjects?
data.answer: You are advised not to make any changes to the subjects pre-assigned to you by the department without consulting your department/Academic Advisor.

question: What should I do if I need to drop subjects pre-assigned by my department?
Is there a procedure for dropping subjects assigned by the department?
How can I drop subjects that were pre-assigned to me?
data.answer: Students enrolled in undergraduate degree programme and Higher Diploma programmes need to obtain prior approval from their departments should they have genuine needs to drop subjects pre-assigned/assigned by their departments.

question: What is the process for dropping all subjects in a semester?
Can I drop all subjects in a semester without approval?
How do I seek approval for zero subject enrolment in a semester?
data.answer: In case you wish to drop all the subjects in a semester, you must first seek approval from your department for zero subject enrolment. (Please refer to section 4I on “Zero Subject Enrolment and Retention of Study Place”.)

question: What happens if I drop subjects after the add/drop period?
Is dropping subjects after the add/drop period allowed?
What is the consequence of dropping subjects post the add/drop period?
data.answer: Dropping of subjects after the add/drop period is not allowed. If you have a genuine need to do so, it will be handled as withdrawal of subject. (Please refer to section 5G on “Withdrawal of Subjects”.)

question: What can students do to broaden their perspective before graduation?
During which period can students select additional subjects?
When will the selection of additional subjects take place?
What happens if students request to drop additional subjects after the add/drop period?
How are all subjects treated in GPA calculation?
Which subjects are counted towards the GPA for award classification?
data.answer: Students can take additional subjects before graduation to broaden their perspective. The selection of additional subjects will be done during the last two days of the add/drop period. Any requests for dropping the additional subjects after the add/drop period will be treated as subject withdrawal. All subjects will be included in the calculation of GPA while only those subjects within the programme curriculum requirement, including subjects selected to fulfill the Free Elective requirement, will be counted towards the GPA for award classification.

question: What should I do if I have a genuine need to withdraw from a subject after the add/drop period?
How can I withdraw from a subject after the add/drop period?
Is there a process for withdrawing from a subject after the add/drop period?
data.answer: If you have a genuine need to withdraw from a subject after the add/drop period, you should submit an application for withdrawal of subjects to your programme offering department.

question: Who will consider the request for withdrawal of subjects?
What is the process for considering the request for subject withdrawal?
Is there a specific authority that handles requests for subject withdrawal?
data.answer: Such request will first be considered by the subject teacher concerned and followed by the programme leader if there are strong justifications.

question: When will the deadline for requests for subject withdrawal be?
Is there a specified deadline for submitting requests for subject withdrawal?
What is the timeframe within which I should submit a request for subject withdrawal?
data.answer: Deadline for requests for subject withdrawal will be specified by the teaching department and, in any case, it will not be entertained after the commencement of the examination period.

question: Will my tuition fee be refunded if my request for subject withdrawal is approved?
Is there a refund for tuition fees if I withdraw from a subject?
What happens to the tuition fees if my request for subject withdrawal is accepted?
data.answer: For approved cases, the tuition fees paid for the withdrawn subjects will not be refunded.

question: Where can I view the withdrawn subjects in my academic records?
Is there a specific section where I can find details about withdrawn subjects?
How can I check the status of the withdrawn subjects?
data.answer: The withdrawn subjects will be shown under the 'Assessment Result' of eStudent and in the Transcript of Studies.

question: What happens if I fail to complete subject registration on the scheduled date?
What are the consequences if I don't settle my tuition fees by the payment deadline?
What happens if the fee payment is rejected by the bank?
How can I reinstate my registration if it's nullified?
What is the process for applying for reinstatement of registration?
When will applications for reinstatement of registration not be considered?
Is there a fee for the reinstatement application, and is it refundable?
data.answer: If you fail to complete subject registration on the scheduled date, fail to settle your tuition fees by the payment deadline or the fee payment is rejected by the bank, your registration on the programme, including subject enrolment, will be declared null and void and your registration/student status with the University will be removed. It is only under exceptional circumstances that you will be allowed to have your registration reinstated. Applications for reinstatement of registration can be made using Form AR118. Applications submitted after two weeks from the date of nullification of registration will not be considered. A non-refundable reinstatement application fee will be charged before the application is processed.

question: What should I study to prepare for progression through my study?
Where can I find information on assessment methods and criteria?
What document contains information on grading system and academic progress requirements?
data.answer: To prepare for progression through your study and fulfilment of the award requirements, you should study the information on the assessment method, assessment criteria, grading system, and detailed requirements for academic progress and graduation. All such information is set out in the Programme Requirement Document, which will be provided by your department.

question: What does the University emphasize regarding academic integrity?
What standards does the University uphold in examination and continuous assessment?
Where can I find information about penalties for dishonesty, including plagiarism?
data.answer: The University attaches great importance to academic integrity and honesty and upholds high standards in examination and in continuous assessment. In case of proven dishonesty, including plagiarism, the penalty is detailed in Section 11 on 'Regulations and Rules'.

question: What is the normal period of registration for a student admitted in or before 2019/20?
How long can a student be registered in the program if admitted in or before 2019/20?
data.answer: The student has exceeded the maximum period of registration for that programme, as specified in the Programme Requirement Document.

question: When will a student be de-registered if they reach the final year of the normal period of registration for a program admitted in or after 2020/21?
What happens if a student in this category gets an extension?
data.answer: The student has reached the final year of the normal period of registration for that programme, as specified in the Programme Requirement Document, unless approval has been given for extension (applicable to students admitted in or after 2020/21).

question: In what situation will the Board of Examiners de-register a student without exception?
Are there any exceptions to de-registration for students falling under specific categories?
data.answer: When a student falls within any of the categories as stipulated above, except for category (ii) with approval for extension, the Board of Examiners shall de-register the student from the programme without exception.

question: Under what circumstances can the Board of Examiners exercise discretion to de-register a student before the specified time frame in categories (iv) and (v)?
Is there any flexibility in the de-registration process for students with extremely poor academic performance?
data.answer: Notwithstanding the above, the Board of Examiners will have the discretion to de-register students with extremely poor academic performance before the time frame specified in (iv) and (v) above.

question: How does the GPA in the Summer Term affect the progression of students to the following academic year?
Does the Summer Term GPA impact the overall progression of students?
data.answer: The progression of students to the following academic year will not be affected by the GPA obtained in the Summer Term unless Summer Term study is mandatory for all students of the programme and constitutes a requirement for graduation and is so specified in the Programme Requirement Document.

question: What is the purpose of the academic probation system?
Why is the academic probation system implemented?
data.answer: The academic probation system is implemented to give prior warning to students who need to make improvement in order to fulfill the GPA requirement of the University.

question: How is academic probation determined?
When will a student be put on academic probation?
data.answer: If your GPA is below 1.70, you will be put on academic probation in the following semester.

question: What happens if a student's GPA is 1.70 or above by the end of the probation semester?
How can a student get the 'academic probation' status lifted?
data.answer: If you are able to obtain a GPA of 1.70 or above by the end of the probation semester, the status of 'academic probation' will be lifted.

question: Where can a student find information about the 'academic probation' status?
In which section of eStudent is the 'academic probation' status reflected?
data.answer: The status of 'academic probation' will be reflected under the 'Assessment Results' of eStudent.

question: Is the 'academic probation' status visible in the Transcript of Studies?
Where is the 'academic probation' status not displayed?
data.answer: However, this status will not be displayed in the Transcript of Studies.

question: What is the requirement for study load for students on academic probation?
How many credits are students on academic probation normally required to take?
data.answer: Students on academic probation are required to take a study load of not more than 15 credits.

question: What should a student on academic probation do within one week of assessment results announcement?
When should a student complete the Form 'Study Load for Students on Academic Probation'?
data.answer: Students should, within one week of assessment results announcement, complete the Form 'Study Load for Students on Academic Probation' (Form AR150) indicating the proposed study plans and meet with the Academic Advisors to finalize the subjects and number of credits to be taken in the semester following academic probation.

question: When are examinations normally held?
When should I refer to the Academic Calendar for examination periods?
What will be put up on eStudent and the University Portal about six weeks before the examination period?
What should I do if an examination is not included in my timetable?
Where should I contact if a required examination is not in my timetable?
When might examinations be held outside the regular examination period?
In what circumstances might some examinations be arranged before the examination period or on Sundays?
How will students be informed about examinations held outside the regular period?
data.answer: Examinations, if required, are normally held at the end of the semester. Please refer to the Academic Calendar on the AR website for the examination periods. A notice will be put up on eStudent and the University Portal about six weeks before the examination period of Semesters One and Two (two weeks for the Summer Term) advising you to check your examination timetable. You should watch out for the notice nearer the time and check your examination timetable accordingly. If you discover any examination(s) which you should take is not included in your examination timetable, please contact the General Office of relevant departments. Examinations of some subjects may be held, if necessary, outside the examination period if there are not enough sessions for scheduling. In exceptional circumstances, some examinations may be arranged before the examination period, on Sunday(s) during the examination period or the days immediately following the examination period. Students will be advised by the departments concerned in advance in such circumstances.

question: What should I do before the commencement of an examination?
When am I allowed to enter the examination room/hall?
Is it permissible to bring books, scrap papers, or other written materials into the examination room/hall?
What happens if I possess unauthorized materials during an examination?
data.answer: Before the commencement of an examination, you shall not enter the examination room/hall until instructed by the invigilator. No books, scrap papers, or other written materials shall be brought into the examination room/hall. If you possess unauthorized materials during an examination, it constitutes a breach of the regulations, and you will be subject to disciplinary penalties, including reporting to the department concerned, the Student Discipline Committee, and the Chairman of the relevant Board of Examiners.

question: What electronic devices are not allowed in the examination?
Can I bring my mobile phone to the examination?
Are smartwatches with mobile applications allowed during the examination?
data.answer: The use of electronic devices such as iPod, tablets, PDA, mobile phones, MP3 players, electronic dictionaries, wearable devices, databank watches, smartwatches with mobile applications installed or wireless technologies supported, and computers are not allowed in an examination except those which are expressly allowed by the subject offering Department.

question: What should I do with electronic devices if I bring them to the examination room?
Is there any specific action required for electronic devices during the examination?
What is the procedure for handling electronic devices during the examination?
data.answer: If electronic devices are carried as accompaniment, they must be turned off (including the alarm function) before you enter the examination venue and put under the chair in a position visible to the invigilators. If in doubt, consult your subject teacher/examiner before the examination.

question: What are the alternatives if I need to use tables during the examination?
Can I use my own tables during the examination?
Are there any restrictions on the use of tables during the examination?
data.answer: If necessary, you should only use the mathematical or other tables provided. Special tables may only be used after inspection by and with the approval of the invigilator.

question: What should I bring to time the examination?
Is there a clock in the examination venue?
Are Databank watches allowed during the examination?
data.answer: You must bring your own watches to time the examination as there may not be a clock in the examination venue. Databank watches are not allowed.

question: Where should I place my personal belongings in a hall venue?
What should I do with my personal belongings in a lecture theatre/classroom venue?
What is the recommended location for placing mobile phones during the examination?
data.answer: Except for the authorised examination materials, you are required to place all your personal belongings under your chair for a hall venue or take them to the front of the examination venue for a lecture theatre/classroom venue. Mobile phones should be put visibly on top of the bag.

question: What will invigilators do regarding personal belongings?
Do invigilators have the authority to assign specific areas for personal belongings?
How will invigilators handle the placement of personal belongings?
data.answer: Depending on the actual situation, invigilators will have the discretion to assign a specific area for candidates to place their personal belongings.

question: What precautions should I take regarding my belongings during the examination?
How should I handle my valuables during the examination?
data.answer: You are advised not to bring valuables to the examination venues. The University will not be responsible for the loss of personal belongings brought to the examination venues.

question: When should I be seated for the examination?
What is the recommended time to be in my seat before the examination starts?
data.answer: You should be seated at least five minutes before the commencement of the examination in accordance with the seating plan posted outside the examination room/hall, if there is any.

question: Can I leave the examination venue once I enter?
Is there any restriction on leaving the examination venue once the examination starts?
data.answer: Once you enter the examination venue, you are not allowed to leave until 30 minutes after the commencement of the examination.

question: What documents do I need to bring to the examination?
Are there any specific identification requirements for the examination?
data.answer: You must bring your HKID card (or passport for those without an HKID card) and your student identity card to the examination. Photocopied documents are not acceptable.

question: Where should I place my ID documents during the examination?
What is the designated location for my identification documents during the exam?
data.answer: These documents should be placed on the top right hand corner of the desk for inspection by invigilators during the examination.

question: What are the consequences if my ID documents do not match during the examination?
What happens if the identification documents do not correspond to the person taking the exam?
data.answer: A candidate shall be liable to expulsion from the University if the ID documents do not correspond to the person sitting the examination. Legal proceedings will be taken against both the candidate and the substitute in such cases.

question: What should I refrain from doing until instructed by the invigilator?
When am I allowed to read the examination question paper?
What is the instruction regarding the examination question paper?
data.answer: I shall not read or work on the examination question paper until instructed to do so by the invigilator.

question: What must I do in terms of writing and drawing instruments for the examination?
What is required in terms of writing materials for the exam?
What should I provide myself with before the exam?
data.answer: I must provide myself with the necessary writing and drawing instruments for the examination.

question: Where am I allowed to write during the examination?
On what should I write my answers during the exam?
What is the specified material for writing answers during the examination?
data.answer: I shall write only on answer books and supplementary answer sheets provided for examination purpose.

question: Can I tear out sheets from the answer books during the exam?
What is the rule about tearing out sheets from the answer books?
Is it permissible to remove sheets from the answer books during the examination?
data.answer: No sheets may be torn out from the answer books.

question: What is the permitted timeframe for leaving the examination room during the first 30 minutes?
When can I leave the examination room in the last 15 minutes of the exam?
data.answer: You are not permitted to leave the examination room/hall in the first 30 minutes and the last 15 minutes of the examination.

question: What happens if I arrive late for more than 30 minutes?
Is there a time limit for late entry to the examination room?
data.answer: If you arrive late for more than 30 minutes, you will normally not be allowed to enter the examination room/hall.

question: Can I leave the examination room during the exam and come back later?
Under what circumstances am I allowed to temporarily leave the examination room and return?
data.answer: During the examination, you shall not leave the examination room/hall temporarily and return subsequently, unless accompanied by an invigilator.

question: What items am I not allowed to take with me during the examination?
Are there any restrictions on the materials I can bring into the examination room?
data.answer: You must not take with you any written materials or electronic/communication devices.

question: Will the time of my departure and return be recorded during the examination?
Is there a record of the time I leave and return to the examination room/hall?
data.answer: Your time of leaving and returning to the examination room/hall shall be logged down for reference/record.

question: What actions are prohibited during the examination?
Can candidates communicate with each other during the exam?
data.answer: There shall neither be communication among candidates nor any dishonest conduct.

question: Is there any restriction on behavior that may distract other candidates?
What should I avoid to ensure a focused environment for everyone?
data.answer: You shall not do anything which causes unnecessary distraction to other candidates.

question: What happens if irregularities are observed during the exam?
How are rule violations addressed during the examination?
data.answer: Irregularities of any kind will be reported to the Student Discipline Committee for action as appropriate.

question: Can I bring food or drink into the examination room?
Are there any exceptions regarding food and drink during the exam?
data.answer: No food or drink is allowed in the examination room/hall. However, if you need to drink water (to accompany medication, for example) or have any other urgent requirements, you can make a request to the invigilator.

question: What should I do if I need to use an electronic device during the exam?
Is the use of electronic devices allowed in the examination room?
data.answer: In case of any suspected use of electronic/communication devices by a candidate, the candidate concerned is required to show the content (such as call log/SMS/instant messages/web pages) to the invigilator upon his/her request. The invigilator will take a record of the relevant information to assess if any cheating is involved. Invigilators shall then instruct the candidate to switch off the electronic/communication device or remove the battery. The case will then be reported to the department concerned and the Student Discipline Committee.

question: Any announcements before the end of the examination?
At what point will there be an announcement during the examination?
data.answer: A reminder of the time remaining will be announced 30 minutes, 15 minutes and 5 minutes before the end of the examination.

question: How much time before the end of the examination will the reminder be announced?
When can I expect the first announcement before the end of the examination?
When does the 30-minute reminder occur during the examination?
data.answer: A reminder of the time remaining will be announced 30 minutes, 15 minutes and 5 minutes before the end of the examination.

question: What should I do at the end of the examination?
When should I stop working on the answer script?
What is the procedure after being told to stop working by the invigilator?
data.answer: You should stop working on the answer script after being told to stop working by the invigilator.

question: What should I do until I am told to leave the examination room/hall?
How should I behave after completing the examination?
What is the recommended behavior after finishing the exam?
data.answer: You should remain seated quietly until you are told to leave the examination room/hall.

question: What items can I take out of the examination room/hall?
Are there any specific items I can take with me after the exam?
What is allowed to be taken away from the examination room/hall?
data.answer: You should not take out of the examination room/hall any items issued by the invigilator, except the examination papers. Some examination papers, as specified, may not be taken away.

question: How should I leave the examination room/hall?
What is the recommended way to exit the exam venue?
What should I do to avoid disturbing other candidates after the exam?
data.answer: You should leave the examination room/hall quietly to avoid disturbance to other candidates taking examinations in the same venue.

question: Where should I address any complaint about the conduct of the examination?
To whom should I report any issues regarding the examination conduct?
What is the procedure for making a complaint about the examination conduct?
data.answer: Any complaint about the conduct of the examination shall be made in writing to the Head of Department concerned or the Registrar as soon as possible after the examination.

question: What arrangements will be made for viewing the examination scripts?
How can students find out about their individual viewing arrangements?
Can students take the examination scripts away after viewing?
Are photocopies allowed to be made by the students?
What is the procedure for returning the examination scripts?
When should students return the scripts after viewing?
data.answer: Subject offering departments will inform the students concerned of their individual arrangements for viewing the examination scripts. Students are not allowed to take the scripts away or make photocopies and are required to return them to the departments concerned immediately after viewing.

question: How can I check my assessment results?
Where should I go to view my assessment results?
What is the process for accessing assessment results?
data.answer: You can check your assessment results from eStudent at http://www.polyu.edu.hk/student.

question: When are assessment results typically released?
What is the timeframe for assessment results to be available?
When can I expect to see my assessment results?
data.answer: The assessment results are released one day after the results finalisation dates, which are listed in the Academic Calendar.

question: What should I do if I can't complete all assessment components due to illness?
How can I apply for a late assessment?
Within what timeframe should I submit my application for a late assessment?
data.answer: If you have been absent from an examination or are unable to complete all assessment components of a subject because of illness, injury or other unforeseeable reasons, you may apply for a late assessment. Application in writing should be made to the Head of Department offering the subject within five working days from the date of the examination.

question: What documents should I include with my late assessment application?
Is a medical certificate required for a late assessment application?
data.answer: Any supporting documents such as a medical certificate should be submitted along with the application for a late assessment.

question: Who has the authority to approve late assessment applications?
Who decides the means for late assessments?
Who can grant approval for a late assessment?
data.answer: Approval of applications for late assessment and the means for such late assessments shall be given by the Head of Department offering the subject or the Subject Teacher concerned, in consultation with the Programme Leader.

question: If I am allowed to take a late assessment, how will it be considered?
What will be the status of the late assessment in terms of grading?
data.answer: In case you are permitted to take a late assessment, that examination or other forms of assessment will be regarded as a first assessment, and the actual grade attained will be awarded.

question: What is the responsibility of Subject Teachers regarding coursework and examination scripts?
Who finalizes subject grades?
Which panel reviews and finalizes subject grades?
Before being released to students, what happens to subject grades?
Who makes decisions on a student's classification of award?
In cases of de-registration or extenuating circumstances, which body is responsible for making decisions?
What should students do in advance to address factors affecting their assessment results?
Who should students inform about factors that have detrimentally affected their assessment results?
data.answer: Subject Teachers, in respect of the subject they teach, have the sole responsibilities for marking and grading students’ coursework and examinations scripts. Subject grades shall be reviewed and finalised by the Subject Assessment Review Panel (SARP) before being formally released to students and submitted to the Board of Examiners (BoE). The BoE for each programme is responsible for making a decision on the student’s classification of award and on cases such as de-registration or those with extenuating circumstances. It is, therefore, the responsibility of students to make known to Subject Teachers/SARP/BoE/other authorised parties of the University, in advance and through the department concerned, the factors which they believe have detrimentally and materially affected their assessment results.

question: What could be considered grounds for a review of the decision?
In what situations can a candidate request a review of the decision?
When might a candidate's examination performance be adversely affected?
What factors could adversely affect a candidate's examination performance?
Why might a candidate be unwilling to divulge certain factors before a decision is made?
What is required to support a candidate's request for a review of the decision?
What type of evidence must be provided by a candidate to support their request?
When should a candidate present evidence to support a review of the decision?
data.answer: The following may constitute grounds for a review of the decision: if a candidate has evidence to support that his/her examination performance has been adversely affected by illness or other factors beyond his/her control which he/she was unable or, for valid reasons, unwilling to divulge before the Subject Teacher/SARP/BoE/other authorised parties of the University made their decision and of which they were unaware. The request from the candidate must be supported by medical certificates or other documentary evidence.

question: What should I do if there is evidence of a material administrative error?
How can I address a situation where examinations were not conducted in accordance with regulations?
Is there a process for appealing if there is a manifest inconsistency in marking?
What grounds are considered valid for appeal if there are material irregularities in the process?
Can a student appeal based solely on disagreement with marking?
When is a student's disagreement with marking considered an adequate ground for appeal?
data.answer: A student’s disagreement with the marking or with the decision is not in itself an adequate ground for an appeal.

question: What is the fee for appealing against the decision on subject results?
How much do students need to pay for each examination paper when appealing?
Where can students obtain the payment forms for the appeal fee?
Can students receive the payment form through email?
Is there an additional fee for appealing multiple examination papers?
data.answer: Students appealing against the decision on their subject results shall pay a fee of HK$125 per examination paper. Payment forms are obtainable from the Academic Registry Service Centre. Softcopies of the payment form can also be sent to students via email by their programme offering departments or the Academic Registry upon request. If more than one examination paper is involved, an extra fee of HK$125 shall be charged for each additional paper.

question: Under what circumstances will the appeal fee be refunded?
What happens if the appeal is successful?
Is there any possibility of a refund for the appeal fee?
What is the outcome in case the appeal is upheld?
data.answer: The fee shall be refunded if the appeal is successful/upheld.

question: What is the timeframe for a student to submit their appeal in writing?
When should a student make their appeal to the Head of Department?
How long does a student have to file their appeal after the public announcement of their overall results?
What is the deadline for submitting the appeal to the Head of Department?
data.answer: A student should make his/her appeal in writing to his/her Head of Department within one calendar week upon the public announcement of his/her overall results, i.e. the date when the results are announced to students via the web.

question: Who is responsible for handling the appeal if the student is in a department-based programme?
If a student is in a department-based programme, who deals with the appeal?
Who will address the appeal if the student is studying in a department-based programme or scheme?
data.answer: The Head of Department shall deal with the appeal if the student is studying in a department-based programme/scheme.

question: Who handles the appeal for students in Faculty-/School-hosted Undergraduate Programmes?
If a student is in a Faculty-/School-hosted Undergraduate Programme, who is the designated person to address the appeal?
To whom does the appeal go for Faculty-/School-hosted Undergraduate Programmes?
data.answer: The Programme Leader is responsible for handling the appeal for Faculty-/School-hosted Undergraduate Programmes.

question: For which type of schemes does the Scheme Committee Chairman handle appeals?
Who deals with appeals for Postgraduate Schemes or Faculty/School-hosted Undergraduate Schemes?
If a student is in a Postgraduate Scheme, who is responsible for addressing the appeal?
data.answer: The Scheme Committee Chairman shall refer the appeal to the following authorised person: the Programme Leader – for Faculty-/School-hosted Undergraduate Programmes; or the Scheme Committee Chairman – for Postgraduate Schemes or Faculty/School-hosted Undergraduate Schemes.

question: What should accompany the appeal for inspection by the department concerned?
Is there any specific document that needs to be included with the appeal for inspection?
What should be provided along with the appeal letter for examination by the department?
data.answer: The appeal should be accompanied by a copy of the fee receipt, for inspection by the department concerned.

question: What information should be included in the appeal letter?
What does the student need to address in the letter of appeal?
What is required for a complete account of the grounds for the appeal?
data.answer: The student should give a complete account of the grounds for the appeal in the letter, and provide any supporting evidence.

question: Within what timeframe should the department inform the student of the appeal result?
How long does the department have to notify the student of the appeal result?
When should the student be informed of the appeal result?
data.answer: Departments should inform the student concerned of the appeal result within one calendar week after either the announcement of the student’s overall result or receipt of the letter of appeal, whichever is later.

question: What is the next step if the appellant is dissatisfied with the department's decision?
What should the appellant do if they are not satisfied with the decision from the Head of Department?
Is there an option for further appeal if the appellant is dissatisfied with the initial decision?
data.answer: If the appellant is dissatisfied with the decision, he/she may then appeal in writing to the Registrar within one calendar week from the date of the department’s reply.

question: What information should the appellant provide when appealing to the Registrar?
What details are required when submitting an appeal to the Registrar?
What are the necessary pieces of information to include when appealing in writing to the Registrar?
data.answer: He/She should provide the following information together with other relevant documents in support of the appeal: name in English and Chinese; student number; programme title, year and class of study; subject results appealing against; and grounds for appeal.

question: Who is responsible for referring the appeal case to the Academic Appeals Committee?
What is the role of the Registrar in the appeal process?
Who determines whether there are grounds for reconsideration in the appeal process?
data.answer: The Registrar shall then refer the case to the Academic Appeals Committee (AAC), which shall determine whether there are prima facie grounds for a reconsideration of the decision of the Subject Teacher/SARP concerned.

question: What fee must students pay when appealing decisions on de-registration?
How much is the fee for appealing de-registration decisions?
Where can students obtain the payment forms for the appeal fee?
data.answer: Students appealing against the decisions on de-registration shall pay a fee of HK$125. Payment forms are obtainable from the Academic Registry Service Centre.

question: How can students receive softcopies of the payment form for the appeal fee?
In what format can students receive the payment form for the appeal fee?
Who can send softcopies of the payment form to students upon request?
data.answer: Softcopies of the payment form can also be sent to students via email by their programme offering departments or the Academic Registry upon request.

question: Under what conditions will the fee for appealing de-registration decisions be refunded?
In what situation will students get a refund for the appeal fee?
What happens to the fee if the appeal is successful?
data.answer: The fee shall be refunded if the appeal is successful/upheld.

question: What form should students complete and submit when appealing decisions on de-registration?
Which form is required for the appeal against the Decision of BoE on De-registration?
To whom should students submit Form AR149?
data.answer: Students should complete and submit Form AR149 'Appeal against the Decision of BoE on De-registration' to the General Office of the department hosting the programme/award (or to the Faculty/School Office if the programme/award is hosted by the Faculty/School) within one calendar week upon the public announcement of the overall results.

question: When should students submit Form AR149 for the appeal against de-registration decisions?
Within what timeframe must students submit the appeal form AR149?
What is the deadline for submitting Form AR149?
data.answer: Students should complete and submit Form AR149 to the General Office of the department hosting the programme/award within one calendar week upon the public announcement of the overall results, i.e., the date when the results are announced to students via the web.

question: What responsibility does the appellant have when submitting Form AR149?
What details and evidence should the appellant provide when submitting the appeal form?
Who is responsible for making known the details and evidence supporting the appeal?
data.answer: When submitting the form, the appellant has the responsibility to make known to the AAC full details and evidence that would support his/her appeal.

question: Which body will consider the appeals submitted by students?
Who will deliberate the appeal cases submitted by students?
What is the authority responsible for considering appeals against de-registration decisions?
data.answer: The appeal by the students will be considered by the AAC, which will deliberate the appeal cases making reference to the recommendations of the programme-hosting department/faculty and the Faculty Dean/School Board Chairman.

question: What is the fee for appealing against the decision on award classification?
How much do students need to pay when appealing award classification decisions?
data.answer: Students appealing against the decisions on award classification shall pay a fee of HK$125.

question: Where can students obtain the payment forms for the appeal fee?
From where can students get the payment form for the award classification appeal fee?
data.answer: Payment forms are obtainable from the Academic Registry Service Centre.

question: How can students receive softcopies of the payment form?
In what way can students get electronic copies of the payment form for the appeal fee?
data.answer: Softcopies of the payment form can also be sent to students via email by their programme offering departments or the Academic Registry upon request.

question: When will the appeal fee be refunded?
Under what circumstance will the fee for appeal against award classification decision be reimbursed?
data.answer: The fee shall be refunded if the appeal is successful/upheld.

question: When should a student make an appeal in writing to the Head of Department?
Within what time frame should a student submit a written appeal to the Head of Department?
data.answer: A student should make his/her appeal in writing to his/her Head of Department within one calendar week upon the public announcement of the overall results, i.e., the date when the results are announced to students via the web.

question: What information should a student provide when making an appeal?
When appealing, what details should a student include in the written appeal to the Head of Department?
data.answer: He/She should provide the following information together with relevant documentation, if any, in support of the appeal: (i) name in English and Chinese; (ii) student number; (iii) programme title, year and class of study; and (iv) grounds for appeal.

question: Who is responsible for determining whether there are prima facie grounds for a reconsideration of the decision on award classification?
To whom does the Head of Department refer the case when a student appeals against the decision on award classification?
data.answer: The Head of Department shall then refer the case to the Chairman of Academic Appeals Committee, who shall determine whether there are prima facie grounds for a reconsideration of the decision of BoE’s and/or other authorised parties of the University.

question: What are the conditions for a student to be eligible for an award?
Could you list the criteria for eligibility for an award?
What does a student need to satisfy to be eligible for an award?
What are the requirements for receiving an award?
What conditions must a student meet to be eligible for an award?
data.answer: A student would be eligible for an award if he/she satisfies all the conditions listed below: i) accumulation of the requisite number of credits for the particular award as defined in the Programme Requirement Document; ii) satisfying the residential requirement for at least one-third of the credits normally required for the award, unless the professional bodies stipulate otherwise; iii) satisfying all requirements as defined in the Programme Requirement Document and as specified by the University; and iv) having a GPA of 1.70 or above at the end of the programme.

question: What is the minimum GPA required for eligibility for an award?
Could you specify the GPA criterion for eligibility for an award?
What GPA does a student need to have to be eligible for an award?
What is the GPA threshold for eligibility for an award?
data.answer: A student is required to have a GPA of 1.70 or above at the end of the programme to be eligible for an award.

question: When is a student required to graduate?
Could you explain when a student is required to graduate?
At what point is a student expected to graduate?
What triggers the requirement for a student to graduate?
data.answer: A student is required to graduate as soon as he/she satisfies all the above conditions for the award.

question: What happens to a student's registration if they become eligible to graduate or leave the University?
Could you clarify the status of a student's registration upon eligibility to graduate or leaving the University?
When a student is eligible to graduate or leaves the University, what happens to their registration for the following semester/Summer Term?
What is the effect on a student's registration when they are eligible to graduate or decide to leave the University?
data.answer: Upon confirmation of the eligibility to graduate or leaving the University, registration for subjects (including the follow-on term of consecutive subjects) in the following semester/Summer Term will be nullified and removed.

question: How can I apply for graduation for programmes other than undergraduate degree programmes?
What is the process for applying to graduate with a specific award?
When should I submit an application for graduation?
What form should I use to apply for graduation?
What happens if I submit a late application for graduation?
data.answer: Students can apply to graduate with a specific award by submitting an application via Form AR84c to the department concerned in the semester within which they will have fulfilled the graduation requirement. Any late application may cause unnecessary delay in processing and affect the graduation date.

question: How will I be notified of the graduation application results?
Where can I check whether my programme study streams have been updated as approved?
What should I do if I don't receive an email notification about the graduation application results?
data.answer: Students will be notified of the application results by email within 3 weeks after the close of the application period. They can also check their programme study streams (sub-code) on eStudent[http://www.polyu.edu.hk/student > My Profile > Study Information]. If no email notification is received, they should contact their programme offering department for clarification.
